questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a 6-year-old child whose head and neck was burnt in an accident at school? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 18%

 

As per Lund and Browder chart the percentage of burns in this child would be 18%.

 

For the 1-9 years age group, the Lund-Browder chart is divided into the following regions:

 

  1. Head and Neck: 18%
  2. Anterior Trunk: 18%
  3. Posterior Trunk: 18%
  4. Each Arm: 9%
  5. Each Leg: 14%
  6. Perineum: 1%

 

The Lund-Browder chart is a tool used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) of burns in paediatric patients. It is divided into regions that correspond to different percentages of TBSA, and each region is assigned a different percentage based on the age of the patient. The chart takes into account the fact that the proportion of body surface area represented by different body parts changes as a child grows.

 

The chart is divided into three age groups: 0-1 year, 1-9 years, and 9-17 years. Each age group has its own chart with different regions and percentages. The regions are further divided into sub-regions to allow for more accurate estimation of the TBSA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9%: For a 6-year-old child, 9% represents the TBSA of each arm. This does not correspond to the head and neck region.

 

Option C. 27%: There is no single region in the Lund-Browder chart for the 1-9 years age group that accounts for 27% of the TBSA. The head and neck alone are 18%.

 

Option D. 36%: This percentage does not correspond to any single region or combination of the head and neck in the Lund-Browder chart for a child of this age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the Lund and Browder chart is essential for accurately assessing burn injuries in pediatric patients.
  • For children aged 1-9 years, the head and neck region accounts for 18% of the TBSA.
  • This knowledge is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and management of burn injuries in children.

questions.text: An image of a perianal disease is shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Fistula in Ano


The correct diagnosis is Fistula in Ano. A fistula in ano is an abnormal connection between the interior of the anal canal and the perianal skin. It often presents as a recurrent swelling or abscess near the anal verge, which may drain spontaneously. The key clues include the location of the swelling near the anal verge and the history of recurrent discharge, making it characteristic of a fistula in ano.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pilonidal Sinus: A pilonidal sinus is typically found in the upper part of the natal cleft, far from the anal verge, and is associated with hair follicles in the gluteal region. It commonly affects young men with a hairy back and is located above the coccyx, not near the anus. The key distinction is the location; pilonidal sinuses are not found at the anal verge but higher up in the gluteal cleft.

 

 

Option C. Fissure in Ano: A fissure in ano is a linear tear in the lining of the anus, usually caused by trauma or hard stools. It presents with pain during defecation and bright red bleeding but not with a swelling or external opening as seen in fistula in ano. There may be a hypertrophic skin tag covering it (Sentinel pile). Fissures do not have a history of recurrent discharge or a swelling appearance near the anal verge.

 

 

Option D. Hemorrhoids: Hemorrhoids are swollen blood vessels in the rectum or anus and typically present with painless bleeding, itching, and swelling inside the anal canal or at the anal verge. They do not present with the external openings, recurrent abscesses, or discharging sinuses characteristic of fistula in ano.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Fistula in Ano should be considered when there is a history of recurrent swelling, abscess formation, or discharge near the anal verge. It is distinguished from pilonidal sinus by its lower location near the anal canal, as opposed to pilonidal sinuses that occur higher up in the natal cleft.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. X-ray shows widened mediastinum. BP is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute aortic dissection

 

  • Patient with sudden-onset severe chest pain, with a difference in blood pressure between the two limbs, and a widened mediastinum on x-ray suggests a diagnosis of acute aortic dissection.
  • AORTIC DISSECTION is tear in intima of aorta

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS): ACS includes conditions such as myocardial infarction and unstable angina. These conditions typically present with chest pain but do not usually cause blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option B. Acute Pulmonary Embolism: Pulmonary embolism presents with sudden onset dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and signs of right heart strain. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option D. Esophageal Rupture: Esophageal rupture can present with severe chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema, and signs of sepsis. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs. It may cause mediastinal widening but would more likely present with other signs such as subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The classic presentation of acute aortic dissection includes sudden severe chest pain radiating to the neck and back, a discrepancy in blood pressure between the limbs, and a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray.
  • Immediate imaging with a CT thoracic angiogram and lowering blood pressure are crucial steps in management.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of acute-onset severe abdominal pain. The patient is conscious, alert, and hemodynamically stable. Upon examination, the patient reports that the pain began suddenly. A chest X-ray is performed, which reveals some abnormal findings. Identify the condition shown below and its management?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency laparotomy

 

  • Given the clinical picture of acute-onset severe abdominal pain and a chest X-ray showing free air under the diaphragm, the diagnosis of hollow viscus perforation is suspected, and the appropriate management is an emergency laparotomy.
  • A hollow viscus perforation leads to the spillage of enteric contents into the abdominal cavity. This can cause acute peritonitis, a life-threatening inflammation of the peritoneal cavity.
  • Emergency laparotomy is the surgical opening of the abdomen to investigate and treat the cause of the acute abdominal pain. It can confirm the diagnosis, identify the source of the perforation, and treat it, often by repairing or resecting the affected section of the bowel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric lavage:

 

  • Gastric lavage, often referred to as "stomach pumping," is a procedure that involves the insertion of a tube into the stomach to remove its contents. It's often used in cases of drug overdose or ingestion of toxic substances.
  • In the context of sudden abdominal pain and air under the diaphragm on an X-ray, this option is not appropriate since the problem is not related to the contents of the stomach but rather a perforation.

 

Option C. Ultrasound:

 

  • While it can be used in the evaluation of various abdominal conditions, in the context of acute severe pain and a suggestive chest X-ray, ultrasound wouldn't be the primary diagnostic modality.
  • Air (as from a perforated viscus) is a poor conductor of ultrasound waves, which makes ultrasound less reliable in this setting compared to other imaging modalities.

 

Option D. Chest tube insertion:

 

  • A chest tube is inserted between the ribs to drain air, blood, or fluid from the pleural space. This is usually done in conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax, or pleural effusion.
  • While the X-ray may show air under the diaphragm, this air is in the abdomen and not in the pleural space of the chest.
  • Given the acute presentation and the imaging findings, the correct management is emergency laparotomy to address the underlying perforation and prevent further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hollow viscus perforation is a surgical emergency that presents with acute abdominal pain and may be confirmed by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray.
  • Immediate surgical intervention, typically via emergency laparotomy, is required to address the perforation and prevent peritonitis.

questions.text: A young male presents to surgery OPD with a verrucous lesion over the penis as shown in the image. On examination, inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the management of choice in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Partial penectomy

 

  • The question depicts a case of verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor.
  • Verrucous carcinoma is a rare type of squamous cell carcinoma that is locally aggressive but has a low potential for metastasis.
  • The lesion typically appears as a large, exophytic, cauliflower-like growth.
  • The management of choice for verrucous carcinoma of the penis is partial penectomy.
  • This surgical procedure involves removing the affected portion of the penis to ensure complete excision of the tumor while preserving as much of the penile structure and function as possible.
  • This approach helps in preventing local recurrence and provides a definitive treatment for the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO2 laser ablation: CO2 laser ablation is a treatment option for in-situ carcinoma, such as Bowen’s disease or penile intra-epithelial neoplasm. It is effective in treating superficial lesions but is not adequate for managing verrucous carcinoma due to its deeper and locally invasive nature.

 

Option B. Podophylline: Podophylline is a topical treatment commonly used for genital warts caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). It is not appropriate for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires a more definitive surgical approach.

 

Option C. Topical 5-Fluoro uracil: Topical 5-Fluoro uracil is used in the treatment of in-situ carcinoma or Bowen’s disease. It is not suitable for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires surgical excision due to its locally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor, is best managed by partial penectomy to ensure complete removal of the tumor and prevent local recurrence.
  • This approach is necessary due to the locally aggressive behavior of the tumor, which cannot be adequately treated with topical or minimally invasive methods.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the otolaryngology clinic with complaints of pain and swelling in the right side of his face. Upon examination, the physician noted swelling in the parotid gland, which is located in the cheek area. The patient also reported that his symptoms worsened when he ate food, and he had lost his appetite due to the discomfort. The physician ordered an ultrasound imaging of the salivary glands, which revealed the presence of multiple hyper-echoic areas within the parotid gland. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sialolithiasis

 

  • Sialolithiasis is a condition where a stone or calculus forms within a salivary gland or duct.
  • This condition is most commonly found in the submandibular gland but can also occur in the parotid gland and other salivary glands.
  • Sialolithiasis can cause symptoms such as pain, swelling, and tenderness in the affected gland, difficulty opening the mouth, and dry mouth, especially during eating when salivary secretion increases (known as Meal time syndrome).
  • The stones themselves can sometimes be palpated and can be seen on imaging studies like ultrasound, which might display hyper-echoic (darker) areas representing the stones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foreign body: A foreign body in the context of the parotid gland could refer to any external object that has somehow made its way into the gland or its duct. It's an uncommon occurrence for a foreign body to be located in the salivary glands. Typically, if someone were to suspect a foreign body, there would likely be a history of trauma or an incident where the foreign object could have entered the gland.

 

Option C. Osteoma of the floor of the mouth: Osteoma is a benign bone tumor. An osteoma of the floor of the mouth would represent an abnormal growth of bone within that specific region. It wouldn't typically be a cause of parotid gland swelling or discomfort. Moreover, osteomas are more radiopaque and wouldn't typically present as hyper-echoic areas on an ultrasound.

 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy refers to the enlargement of lymph nodes in the cervical (neck) region. Enlarged lymph nodes can be due to various causes, including infections, inflammatory conditions, or malignancies. While they can be present near the parotid gland, they are distinct from it. Swelling of the lymph nodes wouldn't typically cause pain that worsens during eating, as described in the patient's symptoms.

 

Given the symptoms described, especially the pain that worsens with eating, and the ultrasound findings, Sialolithiasis (option A) is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sialolithiasis, characterized by the formation of calculi in the salivary glands, typically presents with pain and swelling, especially during meals.
  • Ultrasound imaging can identify hyper-echoic areas representing the stones, helping in the diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, speaks inappropriately, and withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus. What is his GCS score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) E2V3M4

 

The GCS score of this patient is E2V3M4

 

  • Opening eves to a painful stimulus - E2
  • Speak inappropriately - V3
  • Withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus - M4

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is an essential tool for assessing the level of consciousness in patients with traumatic brain injury.
  • It involves evaluating the eye opening response, verbal response, and motor response, with scores ranging from 3 (deep coma) to 15 (fully awake).
  •  Understanding how to correctly assess and calculate the GCS score is crucial for determining the severity of the injury and guiding appropriate medical intervention.

questions.text: Patient presents with urinary complaints with sterile pyuria on urine-analysis. A cystoscopy shows dilated ureteric orifice. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Golf hole ureteric orifice

 

The clinical scenario describes a patient with urinary complaints and sterile pyuria, a condition where white blood cells are present in the urine without bacterial infection. The cystoscopy reveals a dilated ureteric orifice, which is characteristic of a golf hole ureteric orifice. This condition can occur due to functional obstruction or vesicoureteral reflux, where the ureteric orifice becomes dilated and appears abnormal on cystoscopy.

 

The key diagnostic clue here is the sterile pyuria combined with the specific appearance of the ureteric orifice on cystoscopy, pointing directly to a golf hole ureteric orifice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bladder diverticuli: Bladder diverticuli are pouches that form on the bladder wall and would appear as sac-like outpouchings rather than a dilated ureteric orifice. They are not typically associated with sterile pyuria.

 

Option C. Bladder ulcer: Bladder ulcers are characterized by mucosal erosions within the bladder and do not present with a dilated ureteric orifice. They may cause hematuria and pain rather than sterile pyuria.

 

Option D. Cystitis: Cystitis refers to inflammation of the bladder, often due to infection. It typically presents with symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, and dysuria. In cystitis, cystoscopy would show diffuse bladder wall inflammation rather than a dilated ureteric orifice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A dilated ureteric orifice seen on cystoscopy in a patient with sterile pyuria is indicative of a golf hole ureteric orifice, a condition where the orifice is abnormally dilated, often due to reflux or functional obstruction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the clinic with complaints of oral ulcers and a burning sensation in the mouth. A picture of the patient's oral cavity is provided, which reveals several white patches on the tongue and inner cheek. Based on this presentation, what is the likely diagnosis for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leukoplakia

 

  • Leukoplakia is characterized by the presence of white patches on the oral mucosa, which cannot be scraped off.
  • The patches may vary in appearance, from smooth to rough or nodular.
  • Common risk factors include tobacco use (both smoking and smokeless forms) and chronic alcohol consumption.
  • While it's a benign lesion, there is a risk of malignant transformation, which is why regular monitoring and biopsy of suspicious areas are vital.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erythroplakia: Erythroplakia is less common than leukoplakia but has a higher potential for being either cancerous at the time of diagnosis or becoming malignant later. It appears as red patches or plaques and is often more concerning due to its higher risk of malignancy.

 

Option C. Submucosal fibrosis: Oral submucous fibrosis is a chronic, progressive scarring disease, mostly linked to areca nut (betel nut) chewing. It's particularly prevalent in the Indian subcontinent. It's characterized by stiffness of the oral mucosa leading to trismus (difficulty in opening the mouth), burning sensation on eating spicy food, and oral ulcers. Over time, the condition can progress, making it hard for the patient to open their mouth. This condition also has a risk of malignant transformation, and like leukoplakia, requires regular monitoring.

 

Option D. Malakoplakia: Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory condition that can affect various organs, including the bladder, kidneys, and even the gastrointestinal tract. In the context of the oral cavity, it's extremely rare. It presents as soft yellow plaques. Histologically, it's characterized by the presence of unique cells called "Michaelis-Gutmann bodies".

 

  • Given the presentation described - white patches on the tongue and inner cheek of a chronic alcohol abuser - the diagnosis of leukoplakia (option A) is the most probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leukoplakia is an oral mucosal lesion characterized by white patches that cannot be scraped off and is commonly associated with tobacco and alcohol use.
  • It has the potential for malignant transformation, necessitating regular monitoring and biopsy of suspicious areas.

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency department with sudden hematemesis. He has been taking aspirin for his arthritis and drinks alcohol occasionally. He gives a history of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, there is no abdominal mass or tenderness. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peptic ulcer

 

  • This patient most likely has a bleeding peptic ulcer.
  •  Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) includes both gastric and duodenal ulcers.
  •  Aspirin, an NSAID, interferes with the protective role of prostaglandins on the gastric and duodenal mucosa, increasing the risk of peptic ulcer formation in the stomach and the duodenum.
  •  Common presentations of peptic ulcers include pain in the epigastrium, bleeding, and vomiting.
  • The history of aspirin use and alcohol consumption further supports the diagnosis of a peptic ulcer.

 

Peptic Ulcer Disease (PUD)

 

  • Etiology: Helicobacter pylori infection and NSAID use.
  • Mechanism: NSAIDs like aspirin disrupt the protective mucosal layer, leading to ulcer formation.
  • Symptoms: Epigastric pain, hematemesis, melena.
  • Sequelae:
    • Bleeding (more common in duodenal ulcers)
    • Perforation leading to peritonitis
    • Stricture causing gastric outlet obstruction
    • Malignancy risk (only in gastric ulcers)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mallory-Weiss:

 

  • Occurs following repeated vomiting or retching, often associated with an alcoholic binge.
  • Characterized by mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Presents with self-limiting hematemesis, not usually profuse.

 

Option B. Esophagitis:

 

  • Inflammation of the esophagus, often due to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • Results in chronic blood loss and commonly presents as anemia rather than sudden hematemesis.
  • Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation, and dysphagia.

 

Option D. Esophageal varices:

 

  • Dilated submucosal veins in the lower esophagus, often due to portal hypertension.
  • Common in patients with liver cirrhosis.
  • Presents with massive hematemesis, splenomegaly, and ascites, none of which are described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a common cause of sudden hematemesis, especially in patients with risk factors such as NSAID use (e.g., aspirin) and occasional alcohol consumption.
  • Recognition of these risk factors is crucial in diagnosing and managing PUD effectively.

choices.text: Spread of tumor to anterior chest wall

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman discovered a lump in her breast during a self-examination. She immediately scheduled an appointment with her primary care physician for further evaluation. On examination by the doctor this was noticed.  What is the cause for the following skin change? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Infiltration of subdermal lymphatics

 

  • When the subdermal lymphatic vessels, which are responsible for draining lymph fluid from the tissues, are infiltrated or blocked by cancer cells, it can cause edema or swelling in the skin.
  • This can lead to skin changes resembling the dimpled surface of an orange, known as "peau d'orange."
  • The infiltration of subdermal lymphatics with tumor cells leads to the appearance of skin thickening and pores becoming more prominent, which is characteristic of peau d'orange.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Infiltration of lactiferous duct: Infiltration or blockage of these ducts might lead to nipple retraction.

 

Option C. Involvement of Cooper's ligament: Cooper's ligaments are fibrous tissues that provide structural support to the breast. They help in maintaining the shape and position of the breast. Cancer can invade these ligaments and cause dimpling.

 

Option D. Spread of tumor to anterior chest wall: If a breast tumor spreads to the anterior chest wall, it can cause fixation of the breast to the chest, making the breast immobile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peau d'orange is a skin change indicative of underlying breast cancer where subdermal lymphatic infiltration leads to edema and skin dimpling resembling the surface of an orange.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the treatment of a patient who presented with the following as shown in the image? Earlier the abdominal mass was reducible, but now it has become irreducible. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Umbilical excision with herniorrhaphy

 

The clinical scenario presented is that of an umbilical hernia that was previously reducible but has now become irreducible. This suggests the hernia has become complicated, possibly due to incarceration or strangulation, where the contents are trapped, leading to ischemia or gangrene of the herniated tissue. The overlying skin also appears gangrenous and requires excision.

 

The correct management involves surgical intervention to excise the affected umbilical tissue and perform herniorrhaphy, which is a repair of the hernia without the use of a mesh, particularly when there are complications such as strangulation or infection. The surgical approach must address both the excision of compromised tissue and the closure of the hernial defect to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical excision: This option only addresses the excision of the skin and does not treat the underlying hernia. Simply excising the umbilical tissue will not resolve the hernia defect or prevent recurrence, making this option inadequate.

 

Option C. Antibiotics: Antibiotics alone are not a definitive treatment for a hernia. While antibiotics may be used if there is an associated infection, they do not resolve the underlying mechanical problem of a hernia.

 

Option D. Incision and drainage: This procedure is appropriate for abscesses and localized infections but not for hernias. There is no indication of an abscess in this scenario; rather, it is a hernia with possible ischemic or gangrenous changes, requiring surgical repair rather than drainage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of complicated umbilical hernias, especially when the hernia becomes irreducible, surgical intervention with umbilical excision and herniorrhaphy is necessary to repair the hernia and prevent further complications.

questions.text: Identify the level of amputation: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Below Knee

 

The correct answer is Below Knee amputation. In the provided image, the amputation level shows both the tibia and fibula bones, indicating that the amputation is below the knee. A below knee amputation preserves the knee joint, which is crucial for improved mobility and prosthetic fitting compared to an above knee amputation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Above Knee: In an above knee amputation, only the femur would be visible as the amputation occurs above the knee joint, which is not the case in the image provided.

 

Option C. Lis Franc: A Lis Franc amputation is a type of foot amputation that involves the tarsometatarsal joints.

 

Option D. Chopart: A Chopart amputation involves a disarticulation through the midfoot, specifically at the talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints. The image does not show the foot structures required for a Chopart amputation, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a below knee amputation, both the tibia and fibula bones are visible, distinguishing it from above knee and foot-level amputations like Lis Franc and Chopart.

questions.text: An intra-operative image of a child undergoing inguinal hernia repair is shown, with a marked vein in the spermatic cord. What is the likely structure? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Testicular vein

 

During an open inguinal hernia repair, especially in the context of congenital hernias, the structures encountered within the spermatic cord are crucial for identification and preservation. The testicular vein is one of the primary veins associated with the spermatic cord, alongside the testicular artery and vas deferens. This vein is responsible for draining blood from the testes and is often seen during inguinal hernia repairs.

 

In the provided intraoperative image, the marked structure is consistent with the testicular vein due to its anatomical position and its association with the spermatic cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral vein: The femoral vein lies posterior to the inguinal canal and is not encountered during an open inguinal hernia repair. It is located within the femoral triangle and is not related to the spermatic cord.

 

Option B. Obturator vein: The obturator vein is also located posterior to the inguinal canal, passing through the obturator foramen. It is not visible or involved in inguinal hernia repairs as it lies deep in the pelvis.

 

Option D. Inferior epigastric vein: The inferior epigastric vein is positioned anterior to the peritoneum and supplies the anterior abdominal wall. It does not travel within the spermatic cord and would not be seen during an open hernia repair involving the spermatic cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an open inguinal hernia repair, the primary veins associated with the spermatic cord are the testicular veins. Other veins such as the femoral, obturator, and inferior epigastric veins are located posterior to the inguinal canal and are not seen within the spermatic cord during such procedures.

questions.text: Image of a patient with large ulcerated breast cancer with liver metastasis. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Simple mastectomy

 

The patient in the image has a large ulcerated breast tumor with confirmed liver metastasis, classifying the cancer as stage IV (T4, M1). In cases of stage IV breast cancer with distant metastasis, the primary goal of management shifts from curative to palliative care, focusing on improving quality of life and managing symptoms.

For patients with large ulcerated tumors, palliative simple mastectomy may be considered to alleviate symptoms like pain, ulceration, discharge, or infection, which can significantly impact the patient’s quality of life. This procedure is not intended to cure but to provide local control of the tumor and improve comfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRM (Modified Radical Mastectomy): This is a more aggressive surgical approach that involves removal of the breast tissue along with axillary lymph nodes. It is typically reserved for curative intent in earlier stages of breast cancer without distant metastasis. It is not appropriate for palliation in stage IV disease with liver metastasis.

 

Option C. Radical mastectomy: This involves removal of the entire breast, underlying chest muscles, and axillary lymph nodes. This extensive procedure is rarely performed today and is not suitable for palliative care in metastatic disease due to its high morbidity without a survival benefit.

 

Option D. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is used in locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) to shrink tumors before surgery, but in the presence of distant metastasis (M1), systemic chemotherapy alone would be preferred for palliative purposes. Surgery would only follow if there was a significant symptomatic tumor burden requiring local control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with stage IV breast cancer with distant metastasis, such as liver metastasis, the primary focus is on palliation. Simple mastectomy may be performed to manage symptoms from a large ulcerated tumor, but more extensive surgeries or curative approaches are not indicated.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. Upon examination, it is found that the patient is unable to pass urine and there is visible blood at the meatus. A retrograde urethrogram was performed as shown below. What is the most likely site of urethral injury? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Membranous urethra

 

  • Given the presentation of the patient - specifically the inability to pass urine, visible blood at the meatus after a motor vehicle accident and the RGU appearance - the membranous urethra is the most likely site of injury.
  • This is because it's closely associated with pelvic fractures, which are common in such accidents.
  • The management includes a retrograde urethrogram to confirm the injury, followed by the insertion of a suprapubic catheter to bypass the injured segment and allow for healing.
  • Membranous urethral rupture is typically associated with pelvic fractures and presents with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and a high-riding prostate on digital examination.
  • Bruising may also be visible over the pubic area, scrotum, and penis. Urine extravasates in the perivesical space.
  • The membranous urethra is the shortest and narrowest part of the male urethra and passes through the urogenital diaphragm.
  • This segment is particularly vulnerable in cases of pelvic fractures, often seen in motor vehicle accidents.
  • Clinical features, such as blood at the meatus and urinary retention as seen in the case, often point to an injury in this region.
  • On rectal examination, a high-riding prostate may be palpated, indicating disruption of the urethra below the prostate. This choice aligns with the given scenario and is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulbar Urethra: It's a common site of injury due to straddle injuries (like falling onto a bicycle crossbar) because of its exposed location. It would typically result in a perineal hematoma.

 

Option B. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture: This occurs due to a blow to the pelvis; however, no blood is seen at the urethral meatus.

 

Option D. Penile Urethra: This portion is within the shaft of the penis, encased within the corpus spongiosum. Trauma to the penile urethra usually results from direct trauma to the penis, such as in the context of a penile fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Membranous urethral injuries are common in pelvic fractures, presenting with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and possibly a high-riding prostate on rectal examination. Retrograde urethrogram is used for confirmation.

questions.text: A patient suffering from leprosy develops a dirty wound on his foot. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Debride and dressing

 

The image shows a lower limb ulcer in a patient with a history of leprosy. This type of ulcer is typically neuropathic or trophic due to nerve damage caused by leprosy, leading to decreased sensation and subsequent injury. The first and most crucial step in managing such ulcers is debridement and proper dressing. Debridement removes necrotic tissue, slough, and any other debris, which promotes a clean wound environment conducive to healing. Proper dressing keeps the ulcer protected and aids in healing by maintaining an optimal moisture balance.

 

Subsequent steps after debridement include appropriate foot care, offloading pressure from the affected area, and limb rehabilitation to prevent recurrence. However, the immediate next step is to clean the wound, making debridement and dressing the correct initial intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start MDT: Multi-drug therapy (MDT) is the treatment for leprosy to address the underlying infection but does not directly contribute to the healing of an existing ulcer. While MDT is crucial for treating leprosy, it does not manage the wound directly and should not be the first step in ulcer management.

 

Option C. Foot care, limb rehabilitation: Foot care and rehabilitation are essential components of managing neuropathic ulcers, especially in preventing further injuries and recurrences. However, these measures alone will not heal an existing dirty or necrotic ulcer. The ulcer must be cleaned and dressed first before these steps can be effective.

 

Option D. Deformity correction: This will help in healing of ulcer at a later stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of a neuropathic or trophic ulcer in a leprosy patient, the first step should be debridement and dressing to clean the wound. This is followed by comprehensive foot care and rehabilitation to support healing and prevent recurrence.

choices.text: Superficial from border with normal tissue

questions.text: A patient presents with a growth on the lip as shown. How is the biopsy taken? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superficial from border with normal tissue

 

In cases of ulcerative growths, such as squamous cell carcinoma of the lip, the biopsy is typically taken from the border of the ulcer where the tissue is actively proliferating. This method is known as a wedge or edge biopsy, where a small section from the edge of the ulcer and adjacent normal tissue is removed. This approach is preferred because the most diagnostically significant tissue lies at the proliferating margins of the ulcer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incisional: An incisional biopsy involves removing a piece of tissue from the core of the lesion. This technique is typically used for solid masses, such as breast lumps, where a core sample is required to assess the deeper tissue architecture. It is not appropriate for ulcerative lesions where the proliferative activity is at the edges.

 

Option B. Excisional: An excisional biopsy involves removing the entire lesion along with some surrounding normal tissue. While this is useful for small lesions where complete removal is feasible, it is not the standard initial approach for large or ulcerated lesions like those seen in aggressive lip cancers.

 

Option D. Deep biopsy: A deep biopsy targets deeper tissue layers, which may be necessary for certain internal masses but is not suitable for superficial ulcerative lesions like lip growths, where the pathology is best captured at the surface and edges.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For ulcerative lesions, particularly squamous cell carcinomas, a biopsy should be taken from the border or edge of the lesion, including some normal tissue, as this area contains the most diagnostically relevant proliferating cells.

choices.text: Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water
Continuous exposure to cement and concrete
Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.text: A construction worker came to the OPD complaining of white fingers. He has been working in the cement and concrete industry and has been working on heavy machinery drills, wood, and furniture polishing for 20 years. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continuous exposure to drills and machines

 

  • The white fingers suggest the diagnosis of Raynaud's syndrome, which is commonly seen in individuals exposed to vibrating tools like drills and machines.
  •  Raynaud phenomenon is characterized by decreased blood flow to the skin due to arteriolar vasospasm in response to cold or stress.
  • This condition leads to color changes in the skin, transitioning from white (ischemia) to blue (hypoxia) to red (reperfusion).

 

Raynaud's Syndrome:

 

  • Pathophysiology: Arteriolar vasospasm causes decreased blood flow.
  • Triggers: Cold or stress.
  • Symptoms: Color changes in the fingers, pain, and numbness.
  • Risk Factors: Chronic use of vibrating tools (e.g., drills, jackhammers).
  • Types:
    • Primary (Idiopathic): No associated medical condition.
    • Secondary: Associated with connective tissue diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), CREST syndrome (a form of systemic sclerosis), or mixed connective tissue disease. Digital ulceration (critical ischemia) is seen in secondary Raynaud's syndrome.
  • Treatment: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) to reduce the frequency and severity of vasospastic episodes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water: Candidal infections usually cause red, itchy, and swollen skin, often with pustules and a whitish coating. They do not present as white, ischemic fingers typical of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Option B. Exposure to thinners and paints: While exposure to thinners and paints can cause dermatitis and other skin conditions, they do not typically result in the vasospastic changes seen in Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

Option C. Continuous exposure to cement and concrete: Continuous exposure to cement and concrete can cause contact dermatitis and other dermatological issues but is not associated with the vasospasm and color changes characteristic of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Raynaud's syndrome is characterized by episodic vasospastic attacks in response to cold or stress, leading to color changes in the fingers.
  •  Chronic exposure to vibrating tools, such as drills and machines, is a common occupational risk factor for developing this condition.
  • Treatment includes the use of calcium channel blockers to manage symptoms.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the paediatrician with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Upon further investigation, a micturating cystourethrogram is performed and which is shown below. The boy is currently asymptomatic and has no history of renal or bladder abnormalities. What could be the cause of the symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vesicoureteral reflux

 

  • In above case scenario recurrent urinary tract infections and the micturating cystourethrogram showing dilated ureters points towards the diagnosis of vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).
  • Vesicoureteral reflux is a condition where urine flows retrogradely from the bladder back into the ureters and possibly up to the kidneys.
  • VUR is a common cause of recurrent UTIs in children, especially when no other anatomical abnormalities are identified.
  •  The presented imaging findings and clinical history are consistent with VUR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urinary bladder diverticulum: This refers to an outpouching of the bladder wall. It can be congenital or acquired, and these outpouchings can retain urine and be sites of recurrent infections. While bladder diverticula can cause UTIs, the described imaging findings (a dilated ureter) do not align with this diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Urinary bladder hernia: This is a very rare condition where a portion of the urinary bladder herniates into the surrounding tissue or space. It is not typically associated with the findings described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Varicocele : A varicocele refers to an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum. It is not related to the imaging findings described in the scenario or the symptoms of recurrent UTIs in the patient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is a common cause of recurrent urinary tract infections in children. The condition is characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and potentially up to the kidneys. Imaging findings showing dilated ureters on a micturating cystourethrogram are indicative of VUR.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male underwent a bilateral laparoscopic hernia repair for inguinal hernia. Postoperatively, he complained of pain in the right thigh. Which of the following nerve entrapment leads to this symptom? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

 

  • Pain in the thigh (Meralgia Paraesthetica) is due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. This nerve entrapment often occurs during laparoscopic hernia repair, especially during the placement of mesh.
  •  The nerves commonly injured in laparoscopic repair are the genitofemoral and lateral femoral cutaneous nerves of the thigh.
  •  Patients with lateral cutaneous nerve injury present with acute neuropathic pain along the dermatomal distribution, resulting in meralgia paresthetica.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Treatment consists of rest, ice, NSAIDs, physical therapy, and possible local corticosteroid and anesthetic injection.
  • Drugs like gabapentin can be used to manage neuropathic pain.
  • In laparoscopic transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) repair, to reduce the chances of nerve injury during mesh placement, tacks are ideally placed above the iliopubic tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ilioinguinal nerve: The ilioinguinal nerve leads to sensory disturbances and pain over the skin of the genitalia and upper medial thigh. This nerve is most commonly injured in open repair of inguinal hernia, not laparoscopic repair.

 

Option B. Iliohypogastric nerve: The iliohypogastric nerve leads to pain in the inguinal and suprapubic regions. Injury to this nerve does not typically result in pain isolated to the thigh.

 

Option C. Femoral nerve: Femoral nerve injury presents as lower limb numbness, weakness, tingling, paralysis, or pain along the nerve. However, femoral nerve injury is less likely to be caused by laparoscopic hernia repair and more often associated with other surgical procedures or traumatic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meralgia paresthetica, characterized by pain in the thigh, is commonly due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, especially following laparoscopic hernia repair.
  •  Proper placement of mesh and tacks during surgery is crucial to avoid this nerve injury.

questions.text: A patient presents with a tender pulsatile mass as shown in the image below. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT angiogram

  • Cirsoid aneurysm is a rare type of vascular malformation that involves the dilation of multiple blood vessels and their adjacent tissue, resulting in a tangled mass of blood vessels resembling a "bag of worms".
  • These aneurysms are most commonly found in the scalp, face, and neck regions, but can occur in other parts of the body as well.
  • Symptoms may include visible swelling, throbbing or pulsating sensation, pain, and potential for bleeding or rupture.
  • Diagnosis of cirsoid aneurysm is typically made through imaging tests such as USG Doppler, CT, MRI, or angiography.
  • If the pulsatile mass is suspected to be a vascular lesion or aneurysm, a CT angiogram would be a suitable choice as it provides detailed visualization of the blood vessels, and can help define the anatomy and blood supply of the lesion.
  • It aids in planning therapeutic interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FESS (functional endoscopic sinus surgery): FESS is a procedure used to treat chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps. It involves using an endoscope to view and remove the sinus blockages. This procedure is not relevant to the diagnosis or management of a vascular malformation like cirsoid aneurysm.

 

Option B. Needle aspiration: Needle aspiration is contraindicated in this scenario due to the risk of bleeding. Attempting to aspirate a pulsatile vascular lesion can lead to significant hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Intravenous antibiotics for 7 days: Intravenous antibiotics are typically used to treat infections. While pain and tenderness might suggest an infectious process, the presence of a pulsatile mass strongly suggests a vascular etiology, making antibiotics inappropriate as a primary intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A CT angiogram is crucial for diagnosing and planning the treatment of a cirsoid aneurysm due to its detailed visualization of blood vessels.
  • Needle aspiration is contraindicated due to the risk of bleeding.

choices.text: Urethral repair with buccal mucosal graft

questions.text: Patient presents with acute urinary retention, and suprapubic catheterization is done. Urethrogram show a long segment stricture. What is the best management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urethral repair with buccal mucosal graft

 

For long urethral strictures, typically those greater than 1-2 cm in length, the preferred management is urethral repair using a buccal mucosal graft. This surgical approach involves using a graft from the buccal mucosa (inner cheek lining) to replace or augment the narrowed segment of the urethra, thereby restoring normal urine flow. Buccal mucosal grafts are favored due to their durability, excellent tissue characteristics, and high success rates in reconstructive urology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metal catheter: Using a metal catheter is an outdated approach and is not recommended for managing long urethral strictures due to its potential to cause trauma and worsening of the stricture.

 

Option B. Dilation: Dilation is a temporary and often less effective method for managing urethral strictures, especially long ones. It involves stretching the stricture but does not offer a long-term solution and has a high recurrence rate.

 

Option C. Endoscopic urethrotomy: Endoscopic urethrotomy, also known as visual internal urethrotomy, is typically reserved for short segment strictures (less than 1 cm). It involves using a scope to cut the stricture internally. It is not suitable for long segment strictures as it has a higher recurrence rate and limited success in longer strictures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long urethral strictures require reconstructive surgery with techniques such as urethral repair using a buccal mucosal graft to provide a durable and effective solution for restoring normal urethral function.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with varicose veins comes to OPD with complaints of eczema over the same region. What is the stage of the clinical classification according to the CEAP guidelines? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C4a

 

  • The descriptive CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classification for chronic venous disorders is as follows:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C2:

 

  • Description: Varicose veins without any additional skin changes or complications.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, which indicates a more advanced stage than C2.

 

Option B. C3:

 

  • Description: Presence of oedema without skin changes.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, not just oedema.

 

Option D. C4b:

 

  • Description: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, which is classified under C4a, not the more severe skin changes seen in C4b.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • According to the CEAP classification for chronic venous disorders, the presence of eczema or pigmentation in a patient with varicose veins is classified as stage C4a.

questions.text: In a male child having recurrent urinary problems, an imaging as done as shown. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endoscopic Ablation

 

The image shows dilated posterior urethra suggestive of posterior urethral valves. Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are congenital obstructive lesions in the male urethra that cause significant urinary problems, including recurrent infections, urinary retention, and potential renal damage due to backpressure effects on the kidneys. The preferred management for a significant PUV is endoscopic ablation, also known as cystoscopic ablation. This procedure involves using an endoscope to visualize and ablate (remove) the obstructing valves, thereby relieving the obstruction and improving urinary flow. Endoscopic ablation is the treatment of choice due to its effectiveness in directly addressing the obstructive lesion and preventing further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dilation of urethra: Urethral dilation may be used in very early or minor cases of PUV but is generally not considered the primary treatment choice due to the risk of recurrence and inadequate relief of obstruction.

 

Option C. Dilation of urethra and bladder: This approach is not appropriate for managing PUV as it does not address the obstructive nature of the valves and is ineffective in resolving the underlying pathology.

 

Option D. Excision of verumontanum: The verumontanum is a structure within the urethra that is not involved in the formation of PUVs, and its excision would not resolve the problem. This option is incorrect and not a part of standard management for PUV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic ablation is the definitive treatment for posterior urethral valves in children, providing direct relief of the obstruction and reducing the risk of renal damage.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the upper GI endoscopy image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esophageal varices

 

The image shows dilated column of veins in the veins suggestive of esophageal varices. They are seen in portal hypertension and present with hematemesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barrett’s esophagus: Characterised by salmon coloured tongue like patches at GE junction

 

 

Option C. Gastric erosions: Lesions seen in stomach due to H. Pylori.

 

 

 

Option D. Esophageal candida: Appear as milky/curdy white patches.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dilated column of veins in esophagus represent varices.

questions.text: A patient consumed a cleaning product containing 90% sodium hydroxide, having complete dysphagia. What is the best step in management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Feeding jejunostomy

 

  • Since the patient is in complete dysphagia, a feeding jejunostomy is the next best step.

 

CAUSTIC INJURY

 

Most common in children or people with psychiatric illness

 

Alkali poison – liquefactive necrosis

 

Management – Emergency → stabilise the patient

 

  • Endoscopy to assess the injury
  • No perforation – conservative management + feeding by NG feed / NJ feed / gastrostomy or jejunostomy
  • Serial endoscopic assessment – usually after 3-6 months → elective reconstruction → esophagectomy + conduit (gastric / colonic)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophago-jejunostomy : Esophago-jejunostomy is avoided in acute setting.

 

Option B. Stent placement: Esophageal stenting may not be useful if injury extends to stomach.

 

Option D. Gastrojejunostomy: Procedures on stomach are avoided until extent of injury is assessed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a patient with complete dysphagia following the ingestion of a strong alkali like sodium hydroxide, the best immediate management step is the insertion of a feeding jejunostomy to provide nutritional support while assessing and stabilizing the patient.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented in OPD with a swelling that has been slowly growing in the past 2 years. On examination, it was variable in consistency and mobile. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parotid tumor

 

  • The given clinical scenario and image points to a diagnosis of parotid tumor.
  • MC benign parotid tumor is Pleomorphic Adenoma.
  • MC site: superficial lobe of parotid

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid cyst: Seen in children at lines of mesodermal fusion like outer canthus of eye.

 

 

Option C. Sebaceous cyst: Will show soft consistency and punctum.

 

 

Option D. Swollen cervical lymph node – will show firm consistency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A parotid tumor, particularly pleomorphic adenoma, is the most common benign tumor of the parotid gland.
  • It is characterized by slow growth, a variable consistency, and mobility, commonly found in the superficial lobe of the parotid gland.
  • Proper diagnosis involves imaging and FNAC, with treatment typically involving surgical removal while preserving the facial nerve if possible.

questions.text: A patient is found to have a solitary thyroid nodule. What is the first step in his management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Thyroid profile/TSH

 

The initial evaluation of a solitary thyroid nodule begins with a thyroid profile, specifically measuring thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels. This is the first step because the TSH test helps determine whether the nodule is functioning (producing thyroid hormone) or non-functioning. If TSH is suppressed, indicating a hyperfunctioning (autonomous) nodule, further evaluation with a radionuclide scan may be appropriate to assess whether the nodule is "hot" (functioning). If TSH is normal or elevated, the next steps typically include an ultrasound (USG) of the neck and possibly fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy, depending on ultrasound findings. The management plan is tailored based on these initial results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radioiodine with I123: This diagnostic scan is typically used after initial thyroid function tests suggest a hyperfunctioning nodule. It is not the first step.

 

Option C. Radioiodine with I131: I131 is primarily used for therapeutic purposes, such as treating hyperthyroidism or certain types of thyroid cancer, not for initial diagnostic evaluation of a thyroid nodule.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography): CECT is not routinely used as the first step in the evaluation of thyroid nodules due to its limited ability to characterize thyroid nodules compared to ultrasound and potential interference with subsequent radioactive iodine therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of a solitary thyroid nodule is to assess thyroid function with a TSH test. This guides further diagnostic and management strategies based on whether the nodule is functioning or not.

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset perineal pain. On examination, foul-smelling discharge, and necrotic tissue as seen in the image is noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection

 

The given scenario and image is most likely to be of Fournier gangrene which is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

 

FOURNIER’S GANGRENE

 

  • Synergistic gangrene of scrotum and perineum
  • Limited to skin and fascial planes - type of necrotising fasciitis
  • Never breaches the tunica, testis always spared
  • Risk factors - Low immunity, uncontrolled diabetes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases: Anti-gas gangrene serum is obsolete now.

 

Option B. Urinary diversion is the next step: Urinary diversion is not the next best step.

 

Option C. Bilateral orchidectomy must be done: Testes are preserved during debridement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fournier gangrene is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the hospital for a follow-up after undergoing a total thyroidectomy. He reports experiencing perioral numbness that started three days after the surgery. Upon further investigation, the patient has no history of nerve damage, facial trauma, or dental procedures. What diagnostic tests should be conducted to determine the cause of the perioral numbness? NEET PG 2022
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Calcium, Phosphate and Parathormone levels

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of post-operative hypocalcemia, likely due to ischemia of all 4 parathyroid glands or their accidental removal.
  • To assess the possibility of hypoparathyroidism following thyroidectomy, the patient's levels of calcium, phosphate, and parathyroid hormone (PTH) should be evaluated.
  • The patient's symptoms of perioral numbness after a total thyroidectomy raise suspicion for hypocalcemia due to potential damage to or inadvertent removal of the parathyroid glands during surgery or due to their ischemia.
  •  This option is the most appropriate for the patient's presentation. The parathyroid glands regulate calcium levels in the blood, and their ischemic damage or removal can result in hypocalcemia.
  •  By measuring calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels, one can assess the function of the parathyroid glands and determine if hypocalcemia is the cause of the patient's symptoms. If these levels are abnormal, it would confirm a diagnosis of hypoparathyroidism, which can manifest as symptoms like perioral numbness.
  • Symptoms of hypocalcemia may include circumoral paresthesia, paresthesia of the neck, fingers, and toes, muscle twitching, and weakness of the forearm, hand, and foot, as well as carpopedal spasms.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Serum Na, K, and Chloride: Deranged Na/K/Cl are unusual in the setting of thyroidectomy and do not corroborate with the patient’s clinical findings.

 

Option B. T3, T4, Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH): These tests are used to evaluate overall thyroid function. These are not the primary tests to evaluate for post-operative hypocalcemia.

 

Option C. Radioiodine scan: This test uses a small amount of radioactive iodine to evaluate the structure and function of the thyroid gland. It's primarily used in the diagnosis and treatment of thyroid diseases like hyperthyroidism or to detect residual thyroid tissue after thyroidectomy in cases of thyroid cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia is a common complication due to potential damage or removal of the parathyroid glands.
  • It is important to measure serum calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels to diagnose and manage hypocalcemia in these patients.

questions.text: Identify the condition according to given image below.(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trophic ulcer

 

  • Image given is of trophic ulcer, typically seen in diabetic patients because of lack of sensation.
  • They are seen on weight bearing parts of foot.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trophic ulcers, commonly seen in diabetic patients, are typically found on weight-bearing parts of the foot and are characterized by their punched-out appearance with hyperkeratotic edges and undermined borders.
  • They are primarily caused by peripheral neuropathy, leading to a lack of sensation in the affected areas. Proper foot care and regular inspection are crucial in preventing these ulcers.

questions.text: What instrument is used to insert this tube?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Cysto-Urethroscope

 

The image depicts a double J (DJ) stent placed in the ureter, commonly used to keep the ureter patent, especially after procedures like Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) or Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL). The correct method for inserting or removing this stent is through cystoscopy or cysto-urethroscopy, which involves visualizing the ureteric orifices and directly inserting the stent into the desired ureter.

 

Cysto-urethroscopy allows the surgeon to view the bladder and the openings of the ureters, facilitating the accurate placement of the stent without needing to enter the ureter directly. This approach is similar to the technique used in Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) for biliary stenting, where a stent is placed via the ampulla using an endoscope, rather than inserting a scope into the duct itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nephroscope: A nephroscope is used for direct visualization of the kidney's interior, typically for removing stones or other intrarenal procedures, not for inserting ureteral stents.

 

Option C. Ureteroscope: While ureteroscopes are used for procedures directly within the ureter, such as stone removal, the insertion of DJ stents is typically done via cystoscopy, not ureteroscopy.

 

Option D. USG guided: Ultrasound guidance is not commonly used for placing ureteral stents as it does not provide the visual access needed to navigate the ureteric orifices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The insertion of a double J stent in the ureter is performed using a cysto-urethroscope, which allows for direct visualization of the bladder and ureteric orifices, enabling accurate stent placement.

questions.text: Based on the symptoms reported by the patient, what could be the possible diagnosis for a 30-year-old man who has been experiencing recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for the past four years? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fistula in ano

 

  • A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract or channel that develops between the anal canal and the skin around the anus.
  • It is usually caused by an infected anal gland or abscess that fails to heal.
  • The symptoms of a fistula in ano may include pain, swelling, discharge of pus or blood, and recurrent abscesses around the anus.
  • Diagnosis of a fistula in ano is typically made by a physical examination and medical history review.
  • Imaging studies such as MRI or ultrasound may also be used to determine the extent and location of the fistula.
  • Given the patient's chronic history of recurrent discharge and pain around the anus for four years, a fistula in ano is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pilonidal sinus: A pilonidal sinus is a small cyst or abscess that occurs in the cleft at the top of the natal cleft. It often contains hair and skin debris. Common symptoms include pain, redness, and swelling in the area of the buttocks crease, and sometimes it can release pus. Given that the patient's symptoms are around the anus and involve recurrent discharge and pain for several years, a pilonidal sinus, which primarily occurs in the cleft of the buttocks, is less likely.

 

Option B. Carbuncle: A carbuncle is an infective gangrene seen on the back or chest wall. Carbuncles can lead to the formation of an abscess, and symptoms might include a lump filled with pus, which might weep or ooze. While carbuncles can form on any part of the body, their acute and more widespread nature differs from the chronic, recurrent discharge around the anus described by the patient.

 

Option C. Boil: A boil, or furuncle, is a skin infection that starts in a hair follicle or oil gland. It typically starts as a reddened and tender area, which becomes hard and then softens as it fills with pus. Boils can occur anywhere on the body, but they're more common on the face, neck, armpits, buttocks, and thighs. Again, given the chronic and recurrent nature of the patient's symptoms specifically around the anus, a singular boil wouldn't match this presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract that typically develops between the anal canal and the perianal skin, usually due to a previously untreated or inadequately treated abscess.
  • The chronic and recurrent nature of symptoms like discharge and pain around the anus is a hallmark of this condition.

choices.text: Scintigraphy (MIBG) followed by focused neck exploration for parathyroid removal
Perform a DEXA scan, and if normal, will rule out the need for surgery
Assess Creatinine clearance, if > 80 mandates need for surgery

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with findings of hypercalcemia of 12.8 mg% and elevated PTH levels is found to have a 1.5 cm mass below the thyroid. What is the next step? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scintigraphy (MIBG) followed by focused neck exploration for parathyroid removal

 

This is a case of primary hyperparathyroidism due to parathyroid adenoma based on:

 

  • Elevated calcium (12.8 mg%)
  • Elevated PTH
  • Mass below thyroid 

 

Management involves:

 

  1. Localization of adenoma through scintigraphy
  2. Minimally invasive/focused neck exploration
  3. Removal of adenoma
  4. Intraoperative confirmation using Miami criteria (>50% fall in PTH level after 10 minutes of adenoma removal)

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Perform a DEXA scan, and if normal, will rule out the need for surgery: Incorrect. DEXA scan is used to assess bone density but does not alone determine the need for surgery in primary hyperparathyroidism with clear biochemical abnormalities.

 

Option C. Assess Creatinine clearance, if > 80 mandates need for surgery: Incorrect. Creatinine clearance is more relevant in secondary hyperparathyroidism associated with CKD. In primary hyperparathyroidism, the decision for surgery is based on calcium levels, symptoms, and the presence of adenoma.

 

Option D. No surgery, only surveillance needed: Incorrect. With significant hypercalcemia and a visible mass, surveillance alone is inadequate. Surgical removal is indicated.

 

Educational Objective: 


Primary hyperparathyroidism with elevated calcium, elevated PTH, and visible adenoma, the management involves localization through scintigraphy followed by focused surgical removal.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with the lesion shown in the image. He had a traumatic injury to the chest one year ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?   (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keloid

 

  • The image shows scar tissue is of a keloid.

 

Here is a comparison between Keloid and Hypertrophic scars:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemangioma: A hemangioma is a vascular tumor that arises from the vascular endothelium.

 

 

Option B.Hypertrophic scar: Hypertrophic scar is limited to margins.

 

 

Option D. Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are benign tumors arising from Schwann cells. Skin manifestations appear in early life, with the development of more than five smooth surfaced café-au-lait spots, subcutaneous neurofibromata, armpit or groin freckling and Lisch nodules.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Keloids are raised scars that extend beyond the original wound margin, are progressive, and do not regress on their own.
  •  They are most commonly seen in individuals with darker skin and may have a genetic predisposition.
  •  Treatment involves silicon sheets, intralesional steroids, laser ablation, and sometimes surgical excision with radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents to the ER with a history of trauma two weeks back with confusion and ataxia. CT scan reveals the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subdural haemorrhage

 

  • The given clinical scenario and the plain CT scan is suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH).
  • Subdural hematomas typically occur due to the rupture of bridging veins, which can be associated with mild trauma, cerebral atrophy, elderly age, or chronic alcohol overuse.
  •  The presentation of symptoms like confusion and ataxia two weeks after trauma is characteristic of a chronic subdural hematoma.

 

Subdural Hematoma (SDH)

 

  • Pathology: Rupture of bridging veins.
  • Etiology: Can be acute (traumatic) or chronic (associated with mild trauma, cerebral atrophy, elderly age, chronic alcohol overuse). Also seen in shaken babies.
  • Clinical Features: Typically presents without a lucid interval; altered consciousness from the onset. Features of raised intracranial tension and neurological deficits may be present.
  • CT Findings: Crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery (branch of the maxillary artery), often secondary to a skull fracture involving the pterion.
  • Clinical Features: Often includes a lucid interval (period of normalcy between two periods of unconsciousness).
  • CT Findings: Biconvex (lentiform), hyperdense blood collection that does not cross suture lines.

 

Option C. Intra-parenchymal Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Most commonly caused by systemic hypertension.
  • Location: Most often occurs in the putamen/globus pallidus of the basal ganglia (lenticulostriate vessels).
  • CT Findings: Intra-parenchymal bleed.

 

Option D. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Bleeding due to trauma or rupture of an aneurysm (such as a saccular aneurysm).
  • Clinical Features: Patients complain of the “worst headache of my life.” Bloody or yellow lumbar puncture. Vasospasm can occur, nimodipine is used to prevent/reduce it.
  • CT Findings: Intraventricular and subarachnoid space hyperdensities represent acute hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subdural hematoma typically results from the rupture of bridging veins and presents without a lucid interval.
  •  CT scans of subdural hematoma show a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with erectile dysfunction and bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest. The patient reports a history of smoking and high blood pressure. Physical examination reveals reduced sensation in both legs and weak pulses in the feet. Identify the location of the lesion? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortoiliac bifurcation

 

  • Bilateral lower limb claudication, weak pulses, and erectile dysfunction are suggestive of Leriche’s syndrome.
  • Leriche’s syndrome is a rare form of peripheral arterial disease caused by the obstruction or narrowing of the abdominal aorta, specifically at the aortoiliac bifurcation.
  • This is the location where the abdominal aorta splits into the left and right common iliac arteries.
  • Leriche syndrome (or aortoiliac occlusive disease) results from a blockage at this bifurcation.
  • Patients with this condition experience claudication (pain in the buttocks and thighs), erectile dysfunction (because of reduced blood flow to the pelvis), and decreased pulses in the legs.
  • Given the combination of symptoms, this location is the most plausible for the lesion in the presented case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral popliteal arteries: Obstruction or narrowing of these arteries could cause pain in the calves or feet, especially after walking or exercise. It would not explain the symptoms of erectile dysfunction.

 

Option B. Bilateral internal iliac arteries: The internal iliac arteries supply various pelvic organs, including the prostate, bladder, and rectum. While occlusion of the internal iliac arteries might explain some of the pelvic symptoms like erectile dysfunction, it's not likely to cause bilateral leg pain and reduced sensation in both legs.

 

Option D. Bilateral femoral arteries: The femoral arteries supply blood to the thighs and lower legs. Obstruction in these arteries can cause pain in the thighs or calves during walking or exercise. However, this wouldn't typically result in erectile dysfunction.

 

  • Given the combination of erectile dysfunction, bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest, and the reduced pulses in the feet, the aortoiliac bifurcation (option C) is the most likely location of the lesion, consistent with Leriche syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leriche syndrome, also known as aortoiliac occlusive disease, involves obstruction at the aortoiliac bifurcation, leading to symptoms like claudication, erectile dysfunction, and decreased lower limb pulses.

choices.text: Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition
This is a case of Meleney's gangrene
The condition is caused by beta Hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial
Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about the given condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

 

  • The image depicts necrotizing fasciitis of the abdominal wall, also known as Meleney's gangrene.
  • This condition is a severe soft tissue infection characterized by rapidly spreading inflammation and necrosis.
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has been shown to have some benefit in managing this condition.

 

Meleney's Gangrene (Necrotizing Fasciitis)

 

  • Clinical Features: Signs of local inflammation, skin gangrene, and features of septicemia such as hypotension and fever.
  • Investigation: Culture swab tests usually reveal aerobes (such as beta-hemolytic Streptococci) and anaerobes, making the condition often polymicrobial.
  • Treatment:
    • Surgical: Radical wide debridement is necessary and may need to be repeated every 24-48 hours to manage the infection effectively.
    • Medical: Intravenous antibiotics are critical to treating the infection.
    • Adjunctive Therapy: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has some benefits and is used as an adjunct in the management of necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition: True: Radical wide debridement is often needed repeatedly (every 24-48 hours) to control the spread of the infection and remove necrotic tissue.

 

Option B. This is a case of Meleney's gangrene: True: The condition shown in the image is Meleney's gangrene, a specific form of necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Option C. The condition is caused by beta Hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial: True: The infection can be caused by beta-hemolytic Streptococci and is often polymicrobial, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meleney's gangrene, or necrotizing fasciitis, requires aggressive surgical debridement, intravenous antibiotics, and may benefit from adjunctive hyperbaric oxygen therapy.
  • The condition is often polymicrobial, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain, swelling and redness in scrotal area. He undergoes a surgical procedure for the same. Based on the image below, what is the likely diagnosis?(NEET  PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fournier’s gangrene

 

  • The given postoperative image is suggestive of the "shameful exposure of testes" done after debridement for Fournier’s gangrene.
  • Fournier's gangrene is a rare but serious bacterial infection of the scrotum and perineum area leading to gangrene.
  • It is characterized by rapid and progressive necrosis (death) of the tissue in the genital and perineal regions and can spread to the surrounding tissue and organs.
  • Symptoms of Fournier's gangrene may include severe pain, swelling, redness, and foul-smelling discharge from the affected area.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment with antibiotics and surgical debridement (removal of dead tissue) are critical in managing Fournier's gangrene, as the condition can be life-threatening if left untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Torsion of testis: Testicular torsion is a medical emergency that occurs when the spermatic cord, which provides blood flow to the testicle, rotates and becomes twisted. This cuts off the blood flow and can lead to the death of the testicle if not treated promptly. Symptoms typically include sudden and severe pain in one testicle, swelling, redness, and often nausea and vomiting. The affected testicle may lie horizontally and be high-riding. Testicular torsion requires immediate surgical intervention to untwist the spermatic cord and save the testicle.

 

Option B. Acute epididymo-orchitis: Epididymo-orchitis is the inflammation of the epididymis and/or testicle. It is usually caused by an infection, which can be either bacterial or viral. Symptoms include pain, redness, and swelling in the scrotal area, often accompanied by fever. The affected area would be tender on palpation. Treatment typically involves antibiotics and pain relief.

 

Option C. Scrotal carcinoma: Scrotal carcinoma would present as a growth or ulcerative lesion on the skin of the scrotum. It wouldn't typically cause the acute, severe symptoms described in the scenario. However, it is essential to consider malignancy in long-standing, non-healing ulcers or growths in the scrotal area.

 

  • Given the severe pain, swelling, redness, and the nature of the postoperative image showing debridement, Fournier's gangrene (Option D) is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is a life-threatening condition requiring urgent surgical intervention and aggressive antibiotic therapy.
  • Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial to improve patient outcomes.
