questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with features of chronic pancreatitis with recurrent attacks and has a 10 mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi present. Which of the following is the surgery of choice? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

 

  • In the given scenario of dilated pancreatic duct with stones, a drainage procedure in the form of longitudinal pancreatico-jejunostomy (Peusthow) is preferred.
  • CHRONIC PANCREATITIS - Irreversible damage to architecture of pancreas.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple’s procedure): This procedure involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and bile duct. It is typically reserved for malignancies or specific inflammatory conditions localized to the head of the pancreas. It is not the primary choice for diffuse chronic pancreatitis with a dilated duct.

 

Option C. ERCP and sphincterotomy: ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) with sphincterotomy can aid in the removal of pancreatic calculi but is not considered a long-term solution for chronic pancreatitis with a significantly dilated duct.

 

Option D. Coring of the pancreas head: Coring of the pancreatic head may be considered if inflammation is limited to the head of the pancreas alone, but it is not suitable for the diffuse dilation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with chronic pancreatitis and a significantly dilated pancreatic duct (greater than 6 mm), the preferred surgical treatment is longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (Peustow procedure).
  • This procedure helps to relieve ductal hypertension and improve drainage, alleviating pain and other symptoms associated with chronic pancreatitis.

questions.text: Which of these is an indication for giving adjuvant radiotherapy in oral malignancy after resection and MRND? (An image of the flap reconstruction was shown).  (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extranodal extension

 

Extranodal extension (ENE) refers to the spread of cancer beyond the lymph node capsule into the surrounding tissues. This feature has recently been added as a significant factor in the staging and management of head and neck cancers, including oral malignancies. ENE is associated with a poorer prognosis due to its aggressive nature and higher likelihood of recurrence. Therefore, it is a major criterion for adjuvant radiotherapy following surgery and MRND (modified radical neck dissection), as radiotherapy can help reduce the risk of local recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple LN metastases: While having multiple involved lymph nodes is a sign of advanced disease, it alone does not necessarily mandate adjuvant radiotherapy unless combined with other factors, such as large nodal size (>3 cm) or other minor criteria.

Option C. T3 tumor: T3 tumors are generally considered advanced due to their size and extent. However, adjuvant radiotherapy is more strongly indicated when other adverse pathological features, such as ENE or involved surgical margins, are present.

 

Option D. Close margin (1.5-2 mm): Close surgical margins indicate that the tumor was resected near the boundary of normal tissue, increasing the risk of residual disease. However, a close margin alone is not as critical as an involved margin (<1 mm) and typically requires radiotherapy only if combined with other adverse features.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Extranodal extension is a key indication for adjuvant radiotherapy in oral malignancy after surgical resection and MRND due to its significant impact on prognosis and risk of recurrence.

questions.text: A patient presents with a lower limb wound as shown. The wound had healthy granulation tissue. What will be used as a cover? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Split thickness skin graft

 

The correct answer is Split thickness skin graft (STSG). STSG is the preferred choice for covering a large, healing wound with healthy granulation tissue, such as a burn or degloving injury. It involves taking a thin layer of skin from a donor site and applying it to the wound. This type of graft covers large areas and is effective in promoting wound healing with adequate tissue coverage while maintaining flexibility. It is generally used on body areas where cosmesis is less of a priority compared to the face, which would require a full thickness graft.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Full thickness skin graft: This graft involves both the epidermis and the entire dermis and is typically used for areas requiring greater cosmetic outcomes, such as the face. It is not generally used for large wounds with healthy granulation tissue, as STSG would suffice and cover larger areas with a better healing outcome.

 

Option C.  VAC dressing: Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) dressing is used for non-healing or chronic wounds that require additional stimulation for granulation tissue formation and wound contraction. It is not needed when the wound already has healthy granulation tissue and is progressing well in healing.

 

Option D.  Flap: A flap is used when there is a need for bulk tissue to cover a deep or complex wound that involves structures like bone, tendons, or joints. Since the wound described has healthy granulation tissue and is not deep, a flap is unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Split thickness skin grafts are the best choice for covering large, healthy granulating wounds, particularly in areas where cosmesis is not the primary concern.

questions.text: Giving TPN (total para-enteral nutrition) in a patient in ICU with metabolic syndrome predisposes to: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperglycemia


Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) in a patient with metabolic syndrome predisposes to hyperglycemia. Metabolic syndrome is characterized by insulin resistance, often seen in conditions such as type 2 diabetes, obesity, dyslipidemia, hypertension, and, in some cases, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Insulin resistance impairs the body’s ability to utilize glucose efficiently. When TPN, which is high in glucose, is administered, the already compromised insulin response leads to elevated blood glucose levels, resulting in hyperglycemia. This is a common complication in patients receiving TPN, especially those with underlying metabolic conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reactive Hypoglycemia: Reactive hypoglycemia is a condition where blood glucose levels drop excessively after eating, due to an overproduction of insulin. It is not typically associated with TPN or metabolic syndrome, as TPN administration generally leads to hyperglycemia rather than hypoglycemia due to insulin resistance.

 

Option C. Hyperlipidemia: While hyperlipidemia is a component of metabolic syndrome, it is not a direct complication specifically associated with TPN. Although TPN can contain lipids, its primary complication related to metabolic syndrome is hyperglycemia due to glucose intolerance.

 

Option D. Hyperuricemia: Hyperuricemia, characterized by elevated levels of uric acid in the blood, can be associated with metabolic syndrome but is not directly induced by TPN administration. The primary metabolic disturbance from TPN in these patients is related to glucose management rather than uric acid levels.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In patients with metabolic syndrome, TPN can exacerbate hyperglycemia due to pre-existing insulin resistance. This underscores the need for careful monitoring of blood glucose levels and management of insulin requirements in these patients.

questions.text: A patient with history of alcoholism presented with right hypochondriac pain and fever. He had an episode of diarrhoea 1 week prior. USG abdomen reveals a liver abscess of around 25 cc in right lobe. What is the next step in management?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medical management

 

  • This patient with USG revealing abscess in the liver most likely has an amebic liver abscess. Since next best is asked, medical management should be started first.

 

Amoebic liver abscess:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PAIR: PAIR (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Re-aspiration) is more commonly used for hydatid cysts and not the first-line treatment for amoebic liver abscesses.

 

Option B. Surgery: Surgical intervention is generally reserved for cases where there is no response to medical treatment or complications arise.

 

Option D. Percutaneous drainage: This can be considered if the abscess is large, at risk of rupture, or if there is no response to medical management. However, initial treatment should be medical management with antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For amoebic liver abscess, initial management should always begin with medical therapy using metronidazole, chloroquine, and diloxanide furoate.
  •  Drainage or aspiration is considered based on the size and risk of rupture of the abscess.

questions.text: Identify the type of drain: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Closed suction drain

 

The drain shown in the image is a Romovac drain, which is a type of closed suction drain. Closed suction drains are used to remove fluids from a surgical site while maintaining a closed system, preventing contamination and infection. These drains have a bulb or collection reservoir that creates a negative pressure vacuum when compressed, allowing for continuous drainage of fluids from the wound site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open drain: These drains, like Penrose drains, are open systems where fluids drain passively onto a dressing or into a container, which increases the risk of infection due to exposure to the external environment.

 

Option B. Semi-open drain: These drains are a hybrid between open and closed systems, but are not as commonly used as purely open or closed systems.

 

Option D. Penrose drain: This is a type of open drain that allows passive drainage of fluids into the surrounding dressings. It is not connected to any suction mechanism or collection container.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Romovac drain is a closed suction drain that uses a vacuum system to actively remove fluids from a surgical site, reducing the risk of infection and aiding in the healing process.

questions.text: An Intraoperative image of MRM (Modified Radical Mastectomy) is shown. What nerve is marked? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Median pectoral nerve

 

During a modified radical mastectomy, careful identification and preservation of nerves is crucial to avoid postoperative complications. In this question, the nerve marked runs on the pectoralis minor muscle. This positioning is characteristic of the medial pectoral nerve, which supplies both the pectoralis minor and major muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle and runs along the chest wall, passing vertically on the serratus anterior muscle, not the pectoralis minor.

 

Option B. Thoracodorsal nerve: This nerve supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle. It is found on the posterior chest wall and runs close to the latissimus dorsi, not along the pectoralis minor.

 

Option D. Subscapular nerve: This nerve innervates muscles such as the subscapularis, teres major, and latissimus dorsi. It is positioned more posteriorly and does not typically run along the pectoralis minor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of a modified radical mastectomy, the medial pectoral nerve runs on the pectoralis minor muscle, distinguishing it from other nerves that are positioned on different muscles in the thoracic region.

questions.text: A child is having fecal discharge from the umbilicus. What is the abnormality? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Patent vitello-intestinal duct

 

The patent vitello-intestinal duct, also known as a patent omphalomesenteric duct, is an abnormality where the duct that normally connects the yolk sac to the midgut during fetal development fails to close. This duct connects the ileum to the future umbilicus, and if it remains completely patent, it can lead to fecal discharge from the umbilicus, as seen in this case.

 

The persistence of the entire duct results in a direct communication between the ileum and the umbilicus, which can cause fecal matter to be discharged through the umbilicus. This condition is also referred to as an enterocutaneous fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Omphalo-mesenteric cyst: This condition occurs when only a part of the vitello-intestinal duct remains patent in the middle, leading to a cystic swelling along the tract of the former duct. It does not cause fecal discharge from the umbilicus.

 

Option C. Remnant urachus: The urachus is a remnant of the fetal connection between the bladder and the umbilicus. A patent urachus would result in urine discharge from the umbilicus, not fecal discharge.

 

Option D. Omphalocele:  Presents with abdominal wall defect with herniation of intestines covered by peritoneum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fecal discharge from the umbilicus in a child is indicative of a patent vitello-intestinal duct, which involves the persistence of the fetal duct connecting the ileum to the umbilicus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents in surgery OPD with midline swelling in the neck. The swelling moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroglossal cyst

 

  • Pathology – Remnant of thyroglossal duct
  • Most common site – midline à Subhyoid
  • C/F – Presents in 2nd /3rd decade of life as midline neck swelling which moves up on tongue protrusion and on deglutition.
  • Treatment - Sistrunk’s operation
  • Long standing thyroglossal cyst has a risk of papillary carcinoma thyroid

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branchial cyst: Failure of obliteration of branchial cleft. Cystic swelling (soft)- typically in a teenager. Swelling at upper 1/3rd + middle 1/3rd junction of sternocleidomastoid.

 

 

Option C. Plunging ranula: Presents as Swelling in floor of mouth, Fluctuation present, Brilliant transillumination.

 

 

Option D. Dermoid cyst: Caused when skin and skin structures become trapped during fetal development.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue is characteristic of a thyroglossal cyst, which is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct.
  • The treatment is typically surgical removal via the Sistrunk procedure.

questions.text: Which patient category is classified as "green" according to the triage system? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ambulatory patients

 

  • The triage system is a method used by medical professionals to prioritize patient care based on the severity of their condition.
  • The triage system typically uses a color-coding scheme to classify patients into different categories.
  • These categories help in quickly identifying which patients need immediate attention and which can wait.
  • Green category: Patients classified under the "green" category are those with non-urgent medical needs. These patients are ambulatory, meaning they can walk and move around on their own. Their injuries or illnesses are minor and do not require immediate medical intervention. These patients can safely wait for medical attention without any significant risk to their health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medium risk patients: Patients classified as medium risk typically fall under the "yellow" category in the triage system. These patients have urgent medical needs but their condition is not immediately life-threatening. They need medical attention soon but can wait for a short period without significant risk to their health.

 

Option C. High risk patients: High risk patients are usually classified under the "red" category. These patients need immediate life-saving interventions due to critical conditions such as severe bleeding, difficulty breathing, or major trauma. Delaying treatment for these patients could result in severe complications or death.

 

Option D. Dead patients: Patients classified as dead or who have injuries that are beyond medical intervention fall under the "black" category. These patients are either deceased or have injuries that are so severe that survival is not expected even with medical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "green" category in the triage system is used for ambulatory patients with minor injuries or illnesses.
  • These patients do not require immediate medical attention and can safely wait for treatment.

questions.text: What is the optimum pressure for VAC? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 100 to 130 mm of Hg

 

Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) therapy, also known as negative pressure wound therapy, is used to promote wound healing by applying controlled negative pressure to the wound area. The optimum pressure for VAC therapy is typically around -125 mm Hg, but a commonly acceptable range is 100 to 130 mm Hg. This pressure range helps to remove exudate, reduce edema, promote granulation tissue formation, and increase local blood flow, thereby enhancing the wound healing process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 70 to 100 mm of Hg: This pressure range is lower than the optimum and may not be as effective in promoting wound healing, as it may not provide sufficient negative pressure to achieve the desired therapeutic effects.

 

Option C. 30 to 50 mm of Hg: This range is far too low to be effective for VAC therapy and would not provide the necessary suction to enhance wound healing.

 

Option D. 10 to 30 mm of Hg: This is significantly below the recommended pressure range and would not contribute effectively to wound management using VAC therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The optimum pressure for Vacuum-Assisted Closure therapy is between 100 to 130 mm Hg, with -125 mm Hg being the most commonly used setting to promote effective wound healing.

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Penectomy with inguinal dissection

 

The correct answer is Penectomy with inguinal dissection. The provided images show a post-operative scenario where the penis has been surgically removed, and a perineal urethrostomy has been created with a catheter in place. Additionally, drains are visible in the upper groin area, which are indicative of bilateral inguinal lymph node dissection. This combination of procedures is typical in the management of penile cancer, where both the primary tumor and regional lymph nodes are addressed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Orchidectomy: Orchidectomy, or surgical removal of one or both testicles, is not typically part of the treatment for penile cancer unless testicular involvement is specifically noted, which is not suggested by the images. The presence of inguinal dissection further confirms that this is not just an orchidectomy.

 

Option C. Debridement: Debridement is a procedure involving the removal of necrotic or infected tissue to promote wound healing. The images do not show the characteristics of a debridement procedure, such as wound cleansing or preparation for further wound care. Instead, the structured surgical approach seen suggests a more extensive oncologic procedure.

 

Option D. Penectomy with orchidectomy: This is combined procedure is not commonly done, and doesn’t depict the images provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Penectomy with inguinal dissection is a treatment approach for penile cancer, involving removal of the penis and associated lymph node dissection to manage local and regional disease spread.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented to the urologist with complaints of abdominal pain and recurrent urinary tract infections. Upon examination, the physician noted tenderness in the lower abdomen and a palpable mass in the right flank area. Further evaluation revealed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelviureteric junction obstruction

 

The clinical scenario and the imaging indicate a likely diagnosis of pelviureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction.

 

  • Pelviureteric junction obstruction is a condition where there is a blockage at the point where the renal pelvis meets the ureter.
  • This blockage can lead to hydronephrosis, which is the swelling of a kidney due to a buildup of urine.
  • PUJ obstruction can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired. Symptoms can include flank pain, recurrent UTIs, and a palpable mass in severe cases.
  • The findings from imaging studies, showing hydronephrosis (dilated pelvicalyceal system), would support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Putty kidney: A putty kidney refers to a kidney that has been extensively damaged by tuberculosis. The kidney appears pale, and is often shrunk, firm, and non-functional. It would not typically cause a palpable mass and recurrent UTIs in the described manner of the patient in the question.

 

Option C. Staghorn calculus: Staghorn calculi are large kidney stones that occupy a large portion of the renal pelvis and its calyces, often having a shape resembling a stag's horn. They can lead to recurrent UTIs and can sometimes be palpable, especially if the kidney is also enlarged due to obstruction. However, the description in the question and the image seems more indicative of an obstruction at the PUJ rather than a staghorn calculus.

 

Option D. Cystic kidney: A cystic kidney, as the name suggests, is characterized by multiple cysts in the kidney. There are several diseases, like polycystic kidney disease, that can lead to cyst formation in kidneys. These cysts can sometimes cause pain, enlarged kidneys, and in some cases, recurrent UTIs. However, the specific findings from the imaging study mentioned in the question don't necessarily align with a simple cystic kidney diagnosis.

 

Given the findings mentioned in the question, a palpable mass in the right flank area, tenderness in the lower abdomen, and imaging results, Pelviureteric junction obstruction (Option A) is the most consistent and likely diagnosis for the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pelviureteric junction obstruction is a condition causing blockage where the renal pelvis meets the ureter, leading to hydronephrosis and symptoms like flank pain and recurrent UTIs.
  • Imaging typically shows a dilated pelvicalyceal system.

questions.text: An intra-operative image of scrotal exploration is shown. Identify the pathology. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Testicular torsion

 

The correct answer is Testicular torsion. Testicular torsion occurs when the spermatic cord, which supplies blood to the testicle, becomes twisted, cutting off the blood supply. This condition presents with acute scrotal pain and is a surgical emergency. The intra-operative image shows a discolored and non-viable testis, which is characteristic of testicular torsion. Exploration in such cases is mandatory to assess the viability of the testis and to perform detorsion or orchiectomy if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Torsion of testicular appendage: Torsion of the testicular appendage, a small vestigial remnant located at the superior pole of the testis, is a self-limiting condition and does not usually necessitate surgical exploration. The testis in such cases remains normal, and the main feature is localized pain without the full testicular involvement seen in the provided image.

 

Option C. Torsion of both: It is highly unlikely for both the testis and the appendage to undergo torsion simultaneously as they are separate anatomical structures. Thus, the option of torsion of both is not realistic.

 

Option D. Testicular hematoma: A testicular hematoma would present as swelling due to bleeding within the testicular parenchyma or surrounding tissue, often following trauma. The appearance would not match the twisted and non-viable look of the testis shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testicular torsion presents as acute testicular pain and requires urgent surgical intervention. The characteristic appearance on exploration includes a discolored, possibly non-viable testis due to the loss of blood supply.

questions.text: How does this graft get nutrition on day 3? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Inosculation

 

In the process of skin graft healing, the nutrition of the graft changes over time:

 

  1. Imbibition (Days 1-2): During the first two days after the graft is placed, it receives nutrition through plasmatic imbibition. This process involves the absorption of nutrients from the wound bed by diffusion into the graft.
  2. Inosculation (Days 3-5): By the third day, inosculation occurs, which involves the connection of blood vessels from the recipient bed to the blood vessels within the graft. This is a crucial step where initial vascular connections start to form between the graft and the recipient site, providing direct blood flow to the graft.
  3. Neovascularisation (After Day 5): After the fifth day, new blood vessels begin to grow into the graft from the recipient bed, a process known as neovascularization. This ensures that the graft has a stable blood supply, enhancing its long-term survival.
  4. Vascular Anastomosis: This term refers to the surgical connection of blood vessels, which is not typically a mechanism involved in the natural healing of skin grafts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Imbibition: This occurs primarily in the first two days post-grafting, where the graft absorbs nutrients by diffusion but not through vascular connections.

 

Option C. Neovascularisation: This process begins after the fifth day, contributing to the long-term survival of the graft through the growth of new blood vessels.

 

Option D. Vascular anastomosis: This is not a natural stage of graft healing but refers to the surgical joining of vessels, which is unrelated to the described natural healing stages of grafts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

On day 3, a skin graft receives nutrition primarily through inosculation, where early vascular connections form between the graft and the recipient bed, allowing for initial blood supply to the graft.

questions.text: Image a of child with an orofacial cleft as shown. When is the first repair done? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 months

 

The initial repair for cleft lip is typically performed at around 3 months of age. According to Millard's Rule of 10, the surgery is ideally done when the infant is at least 10 weeks old, weighs around 10 pounds (approximately 4.5 kilograms), and has a hemoglobin level of 10 grams per deciliter. This timing helps ensure the child is sufficiently mature and robust for surgery, minimizing surgical risks and optimizing healing.

 

Repair of the cleft lip/nose and anterior palate generally occurs between 3 to 6 months of age, while definitive repair of the cleft palate is typically performed between 6 and 12 months of age, as outlined in the provided reference.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6 months: This is the general timeframe for repairing the soft palate but is not the earliest repair. For cleft lip, the first repair usually happens earlier, at around 3 months.

 

Option C. 12 months: This is more appropriate for the repair of the hard palate and definitive palate repair, not the initial cleft lip repair.

 

Option D. 2 years: This timing is not typically relevant for the first repair of cleft lip or palate and is much later than the standard recommendations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first repair of cleft lip is typically done at around 3 months of age, following the Millard's Rule of 10, to optimize surgical outcomes and ensure the infant is prepared for the procedure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented to the dermatologist with a small lesion on her right nasolabial fold. Upon examination, the dermatologist noted a 0.4-cm nodule with a smooth surface and well-defined borders. The nodule was located on the upper forehead, just above the eyebrows. It was excised and a pathological examination was done. The image is given below. What is the diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Basal cell carcinoma

  • The pathological report reveals basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer that is commonly found on sun-exposed areas of the body.
  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer.
  • It arises from the basal cells, which are found at the bottom of the epidermis. BCCs are typically slow-growing tumors that rarely metastasize but can cause significant local destruction if left untreated.
  • They commonly appear as pearly nodules with visible blood vessels (telangiectasia), often with a central depression or ulceration.
  • They are commonly found in sun-exposed areas, which makes their presence on the face, especially the nasolabial fold, quite typical.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery is one of the most effective treatments for BCC, especially for tumors located in cosmetically sensitive areas, as it ensures complete removal while sparing the maximum amount of healthy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma: Melanoma is a more aggressive form of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes, the cells responsible for producing skin pigment. Melanomas are characterized by their asymmetry, irregular borders, multiple colors, diameter greater than 6mm, and evolving size, shape, or color. They can develop from pre-existing moles or appear de novo. Early detection and treatment are crucial as melanoma has a higher potential for metastasis compared to other skin cancers.

 

Option C. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is also commonly found in sun-exposed areas and is associated with chronic sun damage. While it is less aggressive than melanoma, if left untreated, it can grow deeply and cause significant damage. In rare cases, it can also spread to other parts of the body. It shows keratin pearls on histopathology.

 

Option D. Nevus: A nevus, commonly known as a mole, is a benign growth on the skin that arises from melanocytes. Moles are usually brown or black and can be located anywhere on the body. They can be present at birth or appear during childhood and adolescence. While most moles are harmless, it is essential to monitor them for changes that might suggest a transformation into melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer and is typically found in sun-exposed areas.
  • It appears as a pearly nodule with visible blood vessels and can cause significant local destruction if left untreated.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery is an effective treatment, particularly for tumors in cosmetically sensitive areas.

questions.text: Identify the most common site of an intra-abdominal abscess:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subhepatic space

 

  1. The right subhepatic space is a deep space located in Rutherford Morison's pouch between the liver, transverse colon, and hepatic flexure. It is a common site of intra-abdominal abscess (second to pelvis).
  2. Abscesses in the right subhepatic space may occur due to conditions such as appendicitis, cholecystitis, perforated duodenal ulcer, or as a complication of upper abdominal surgery.
    • Also known as Rutherford Morison's pouch, the subhepatic space is situated between the liver's posterior surface and the right kidney's anterior surface.
    • It's a potential space that can collect fluid or pus.
    • It is a common site for abscess formation, especially after conditions like appendicitis, where the infection can spread upwards into this space.
    • Due to its anatomical location and the potential for infections like appendicitis to spread to this region, the subhepatic space is recognized as the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peri splenic space: The peri-splenic space is located around the spleen and is bounded by the diaphragm, stomach, and the splenic flexure of the colon. Abscesses in this space can arise from a splenic infection or trauma, but it is not the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses.

 

Option B. Left subphrenic space: The left subphrenic space is located between the diaphragm and the spleen/stomach. It's a potential space for abscess formation, especially after splenic surgeries or gastric surgeries. However, it's not the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses compared to the right side.

 

Option C. Right subphrenic space: The right subphrenic space is located between the diaphragm and the liver. Abscesses in this space can arise due to infections that spread from the liver or gallbladder, or after surgeries involving these organs. It is one of the potential sites for abscess formation, but not the most common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common site of an intra-abdominal abscess is subhepatic space.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Bladder exstrophy

 

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital condition characterized by the abnormal development of the bladder and lower abdominal wall, resulting in the bladder being exposed outside the body. The image shows a typical presentation of bladder exstrophy, with the bladder visible as a red mass on the lower abdomen of the newborn. This condition requires surgical correction to reconstruct the bladder and close the abdominal wall defect.

 

Other Options:

 

Open A. Umbilical hernia: An umbilical hernia is characterized by the protrusion of abdominal contents through an opening in the abdominal muscles near the umbilicus. It typically presents as a soft bulge near the belly button, which is reducible and covered by skin, differing from the exposed bladder seen in bladder exstrophy.

 

Open B. Omphalocele: Omphalocele is a congenital defect where the abdominal contents, such as intestines, liver, and other organs, herniate through the base of the umbilical cord and are covered by a protective membrane. It does not involve exposure of the bladder and is distinct from bladder exstrophy.

 

Option D. Gastroschisis: It is an abdominal wall defect where intestines are protruding, but lack a peritoneal covering. The defect is usually to the right side of umbilicus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder exstrophy presents with the bladder exposed outside the abdominal wall, requiring prompt surgical intervention to correct the defect and reconstruct the urinary tract.

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis of a 35-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain, whose elder brother passed away due to stroke at the age of 40 and whose ultrasound abdomen is shown below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

 

  • The clinical scenario and the ultrasound image provided suggest the diagnosis of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).
  • ADPKD is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys. Over time, these cysts can enlarge and decrease the functioning of the kidneys, leading to kidney failure.
  • Besides renal symptoms, patients with ADPKD can have other complications, such as cerebral aneurysms (which can rupture leading to strokes), liver cysts, and cardiac valvular diseases.
  • The combination of multiple episodes of hematuria, hypertension, familial history, and the ultrasound findings make this diagnosis the most likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal cell carcinoma: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults. It originates from the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron. It may present with hematuria, pain in the flank or loin area, and a palpable abdominal mass. However, the familial context, with the brother's early death from a stroke, doesn't typically fit with the presentation of RCC. RCC occurs in an elderly age group.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis of the kidney: Tuberculosis (TB) can affect the kidneys, usually as a secondary site from pulmonary TB. This can lead to a chronic inflammatory response. Kidney TB might present with sterile pyuria (white blood cells in urine without bacterial growth), hematuria, and even systemic symptoms of TB like fever, weight loss, and night sweats. The clinical scenario provided doesn't specifically lean toward this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD): ARPKD is another inherited form of polycystic kidney disease. However, it's different from ADPKD in that it presents much earlier, usually in childhood or infancy. Symptoms in ARPKD are typically severe and can include kidney failure and liver problems at a young age.

 

  • Given the combination of clinical symptoms, family history, and ultrasound findings, the most probable diagnosis in this scenario is option B, Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney failure, hypertension, and a higher risk of cerebral aneurysms, making it crucial to consider family history and typical ultrasound findings in the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 4-week-old child with a history of vomiting undergoes imaging as shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Congenital Pyloric Stenosis


The correct diagnosis is Congenital Pyloric Stenosis. This condition typically presents in infants between 3-6 weeks of age with symptoms of projectile, non-bilious vomiting, and a palpable olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen. The ultrasound image shows a thickened pylorus muscle and a distended stomach, which are characteristic findings of pyloric stenosis. The hypertrophied pyloric muscle obstructs gastric emptying, leading to the clinical symptoms observed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duodenal Atresia: Duodenal atresia is a congenital condition usually presenting at birth with bilious vomiting due to a blockage in the duodenum. It is often associated with a “double bubble” sign on imaging. The condition does not fit the presentation of a 4-week-old with the typical findings seen in the ultrasound provided.

 

Option C. Annular Pancreas: Annular pancreas is a congenital anomaly where the pancreas encircles the duodenum, potentially causing obstruction. It usually presents with symptoms soon after birth, similar to duodenal atresia, including bilious vomiting. This condition would not show the thickened pylorus seen in the ultrasound provided.

 

Option D. Volvulus: Volvulus, often associated with malrotation of the midgut, can present at any age, including the newborn period or later in life. It typically presents with bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and sometimes acute abdominal pain. The ultrasound findings here do not indicate the twisted bowel loops characteristic of volvulus but rather show a thickened pyloric muscle.

 

Educational Objective:


Congenital Pyloric Stenosis is characterized by the hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, leading to projectile, non-bilious vomiting in infants aged 3-6 weeks. Ultrasound is diagnostic, showing a thickened pyloric muscle and a distended stomach, distinguishing it from other causes of vomiting in infancy.

choices.text: Excellent prognosis is associated with this condition.
Nuclear characteristics are used for identification.
Fine needle aspiration cytology (FAC) is not diagnostic.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with a midline swelling in the neck. Upon examination, cervical node enlargement is also observed. Histopathological analysis of the lesion reveals the following findings Identify the false statement of the following?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fine needle aspiration cytology (FAC) is not diagnostic.

 

  • The histopathological findings provided are indicative of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which includes features such as papillary formation with a fibrovascular stalk, distinct orphan Annie nuclei, and psammoma bodies.
  • Fine needle aspiration cytology is actually a common and reliable diagnostic method for thyroid nodules, including papillary carcinoma.
  • By extracting cells from the thyroid nodule using a fine needle and examining them under a microscope, the presence of characteristic features of papillary carcinoma can be identified.
  •  Thus, the statement suggesting that FNAC is not diagnostic is false

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excellent prognosis is associated with this condition: This statement refers to the typical prognosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Papillary carcinoma, although malignant, is often slow-growing. When detected early and treated appropriately, patients generally have an excellent prognosis with a high survival rate.

 

Option B. It spreads via lymphatics: While papillary carcinoma often spreads via the lymphatics to regional lymph nodes (leading to cervical node enlargement, as seen in the patient), it typically does so at a slow rate. It's important to note that even when there is lymph node involvement, the prognosis still remains relatively favorable compared to other types of thyroid cancers.

 

Option C. Nuclear characteristics are used for identification: The nuclear features of papillary thyroid carcinoma are characteristic and aid in its identification. One such feature is the "orphan Annie eye" nuclei, which are large, empty-appearing nuclei. Other characteristics, like psammoma bodies, can also be present.

 

  • Given the context and the provided image findings indicative of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, FNAC is indeed diagnostic for this condition. Hence, option D is the false statement among the ones provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a reliable and commonly used diagnostic method for thyroid nodules, including papillary carcinoma, as it can identify characteristic histopathological features.

choices.text: Angioembolization is the treatment of choice
Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and abdominal pain. Investigations showed the given findings. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

 

  • The given CT image shows a cyst in the liver is suggestive of hydatid disease with floating membrane sign.
  • Hydatid disease is caused by Echinococcus granulosus, commonly called the dog tapeworm.
  • MC site of hydatid cyst in human: liver (MC) followed by pulmonary hydatids (2nd MC)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Surgery is mandatory: Surgical treatment of hydatid cyst indicated when PAIR is contraindicated.

 

Option B. Fine-needle aspiration cytology is diagnostic: FNAC is contra-indicated as rupture of cyst may lead to spillage or anaphylaxis.

 

Option C. Angioembolization is the treatment of choice:  Angioembolization has no role in the management of hydatid cyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hydatid disease of the liver, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by the formation of cysts that can be identified using imaging techniques like USG and CECT.
  •  The primary treatment approach includes medical management with albendazole followed by the PAIR procedure or surgery if PAIR is not feasible.
  •  FNAC is contraindicated due to the risk of cyst rupture and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of lower back pain. During the medical examination, it is discovered that the patient has prostate cancer. The medical team suspects that the cancer may have spread to the lumbar vertebrae. What is the likely route of spread for prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostatic venous plexus

 

  • The spread of prostate carcinoma to the lumbar vertebrae is primarily through the prostatic venous plexus or Bateson plexus. Tumor cells spread to the spine and proximal long bones via Bateson's venous plexus, which allows retrograde embolic spread to the spine.
  • The prostatic venous plexus (or Bateson plexus) is a network of veins surrounding the prostate.
  • The prostatic venous plexus has connections to the internal vertebral venous plexuses.
  • Because of this unique venous anatomy, tumor cells from the prostate can enter the venous system and bypass the usual portal and caval routes, spreading directly to the spine, specifically the lumbar vertebrae.
  • This is the most common route for metastasis of prostate cancer to the spine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trans coelomic spread: Trans coelomic spread refers to the dissemination of malignant cells across body cavities, such as the pleural, peritoneal, or pericardial spaces. This method of spread is most commonly seen with primary cancers of the ovary, stomach, and colon. In the context of prostate cancer, trans coelomic spread is not a typical route to the lumbar vertebrae.

 

Option C. Inferior vesical vein: The inferior vesical vein drains the urinary bladder. While there are venous communications between the prostatic plexus and the vesical veins, the direct spread of prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae through the inferior vesical vein alone is less common than through the prostatic venous plexus.

 

Option D. Internal iliac vein: The internal iliac vein drains blood from the pelvis and perineum. While prostate cancer can spread through the internal iliac vein as part of its venous drainage, this route is not the primary pathway to the lumbar vertebrae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prostate cancer primarily spreads to the lumbar vertebrae through the prostatic venous plexus (Bateson plexus), which allows retrograde embolic spread to the spine.

choices.text: Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation.
Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.
Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region

questions.text: Identify the most common neurological complication following ligation of the Inferior mesenteric artery during abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

 

  • An abdominoperineal resection involves the removal of the left colon, pelvic floor, rectum, and anal canal.
  •  It is typically indicated for patients with operable low rectal carcinomas located within 5 cm of the anal verge.
  • The sympathetic innervation of the rectum originates from L1 – L3 spinal nerves, which form the superior hypogastric plexus.  
  • At the level of the sacral promontory, these nerves divide into the left and right hypogastric nerves, traveling on both sides of the pelvis.
  • These nerves supply the rectum and send branches to supply the genitourinary system anteriorly.
  • During pelvic surgeries, it is crucial to be aware of these nerves to avoid injuring them.
  • High ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) near the sacral promontory may injure the superior hypogastric nerves, leading to sympathetic dysfunction.
  • This dysfunction is characterized by retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation: Parasympathetic nerves are less likely to be affected by the ligation of the IMA as their pathways are different. Parasympathetic innervation primarily involves the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4), which are not typically disrupted in this procedure.

 

Option B. Sympathetic - bladder dysfunction and impotence: While bladder dysfunction is a possible consequence of sympathetic nerve damage, impotence is not the most common result of injury to the sympathetic nerves. The more typical outcome includes retrograde ejaculation.

 

Option D. Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region: Loss of cutaneous sensation in the perineal region would more likely result from damage to the pudendal nerve, not the sympathetic nerves. Impotence can occur but is less specific compared to retrograde ejaculation in the context of IMA ligation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma, ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery may lead to sympathetic nerve damage, particularly the superior hypogastric plexus.
  • This can result in neurological complications such as retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

questions.text: The image below shows a pressure sore. Which stage does this belong to?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage 4

 

  • The given image shows a pressure sore with extensive tissue destruction, including damage to the muscle layer and thus it belongs to stage 4.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Stage 1: Non-blanchable erythema of intact skin. Redness that does not fade when pressure is applied.
  • Stage 2: Partial-thickness skin loss with exposed dermis. The wound bed is viable, pink or red, and moist.
  • Stage 3: Full-thickness skin loss. Subcutaneous fat may be visible, but bone, tendon, or muscle are not exposed.
  • Stage 4: Full-thickness skin and tissue loss. Exposed or directly palpable fascia, muscle, tendon, ligament, cartilage, or bone in the ulcer.
  • Unstageable: Obscured full-thickness skin and tissue loss. Extent of tissue damage within the ulcer cannot be confirmed because it is obscured by slough or eschar.
  • Deep Tissue Pressure Injury: Persistent non-blanchable deep red, maroon, or purple discoloration.

 

Treatment Focus:

 

  • Patient Optimization: Addressing poor nutrition and managing ongoing medical problems.
  • Preventative Measures: Implementing strategies to prevent further pressure injuries.
  • Debridement: Removing necrotic tissue if appropriate.

 

Given the extensive tissue destruction shown in the image, with damage extending through the muscle layer, the pressure sore is classified as a Stage 4 pressure injury.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He was the driver of the car, and upon impact, he had hit his abdomen against the steering wheel. Upon examination, the patient was conscious but complained of severe abdominal pain and tenderness upon palpation. The physician noted bruising and swelling in the abdominal area. Further evaluation revealed the evisceration of omentum, which was protruding through a laceration in the abdominal wall. What would be the best management of the same? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Emergency laparotomy

 

  • In the context of penetrating trauma, especially with evisceration (protrusion of internal tissues or organs through a wound), an emergency laparotomy becomes the procedure of choice to address any potential life-threatening injuries, stop bleeding, and repair damaged structures.
  • Evisceration is an indicator of full-thickness injury to the abdominal wall and potential underlying organ damage.

 

Indications for emergency laparotomy in penetrating trauma include:

 

  • Unstable patient
  • Features of peritonitis
  • Evisceration
  • Gunshot wounds

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Observation: Observation alone in this scenario would delay necessary intervention and could worsen the patient's outcome. Immediate surgical intervention is necessary to manage the evisceration and associated internal injuries.

 

Option C. Intravenous hydration: While IV hydration might be a part of the supportive care for a trauma patient, it is not the primary treatment for an evisceration injury. The priority would be to address the traumatic injury directly through surgery.

 

Option D. Wait and watch: This approach, like observation, is passive and is not suitable for traumatic injuries that are obviously severe, like evisceration. Delay in surgical intervention could lead to complications and worsen the patient's prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Evisceration in the context of trauma is a surgical emergency that requires immediate laparotomy to address potential internal injuries, control bleeding, and repair the damage.
  • Prompt surgical intervention is crucial to prevent complications and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters are included in qSOFA score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SBP, RR, GCS score

 

  • The Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) score is used to identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit.
  • The qSOFA score includes three clinical criteria:
    1. Respiratory rate (RR) ≥ 22/min: A high respiratory rate indicates respiratory distress and a higher risk of organ failure.
    2. Systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤ 100 mmHg: Low blood pressure indicates hemodynamic instability and a higher risk of mortality.
    3. Change in mental status (GCS score): Altered mental status, measured by the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), indicates possible central nervous system dysfunction.
  • Each criterion is assigned one point, and a qSOFA score of ≥2 suggests a higher risk of adverse outcomes and increased mortality.

 

qSOFA (Quick SOFA) Criteria

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BP, RR, and CBC: This option includes blood pressure and respiratory rate, but the complete blood count (CBC) is not part of the qSOFA score.

 

Option B. Creatinine, PR, BP:  Creatinine and pulse rate (PR) are not part of the qSOFA score. Blood pressure is included, but the qSOFA score focuses on systolic blood pressure specifically.

 

Option C. RR, Body temperature, PR: Respiratory rate is part of the qSOFA score, but body temperature and pulse rate are not included.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The qSOFA score includes three clinical criteria: respiratory rate (RR) ≥ 22/min, systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤ 100 mmHg, and altered mental status (GCS score).
  • A qSOFA score of ≥2 indicates a higher risk of poor outcomes in patients with suspected infection.

questions.text: A case of urinary bladder stone with a history of Proteus infection is likely to be? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phosphate

 

Proteus infection in the urinary tract is commonly associated with the formation of struvite stones, which are also known as triple phosphate stones. Struvite stones consist of magnesium, ammonium, and phosphate. Proteus species produce the enzyme urease, which hydrolyzes urea into ammonia, increasing the urine pH and promoting the precipitation of phosphate, magnesium, and ammonium to form struvite stones.

 

These stones are often described as "infection stones" because they typically form in alkaline urine in the presence of a urinary tract infection caused by urease-producing bacteria like Proteus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxalate: Oxalate stones are primarily composed of calcium oxalate and are not directly related to infections. They are often associated with dietary factors, hyperoxaluria, or conditions causing increased oxalate excretion.

 

Option C. Uric acid: Uric acid stones form in acidic urine and are related to conditions that increase uric acid levels, such as gout or a high purine diet. They are not associated with Proteus infections or other urease-producing bacteria.

 

Option D. Cystine: Cystine stones are associated with cystinuria, a genetic disorder that leads to the excessive excretion of cystine in the urine. These stones are characterized by their hexagonal crystal shape but are not related to Proteus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urinary bladder stones associated with Proteus infection are most likely to be struvite (triple phosphate) stones, formed due to the alkalinizing effect of urease-producing bacteria on the urine.

questions.text: Elderly male with a 3-week presents with history of trauma, with CT brain image as shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SDH (Subdural Hematoma)

 

The correct diagnosis is Subdural Hematoma (SDH). In elderly patients with a history of trauma, a sub-acute subdural hematoma often presents with symptoms that develop gradually over weeks due to slow venous bleeding. The CT scan shows a crescent-shaped (banana-shaped) hyperdense area, which is characteristic of a subdural hematoma. The chronic nature of the subdural hematoma is suggested by the time course (3 weeks’ post-trauma) and is more common in the elderly due to brain atrophy, which increases the risk of bridging vein tears leading to SDH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EDH (Epidural Hematoma): An epidural hematoma typically presents with a biconvex (lens-shaped) appearance on CT imaging, occurring between the skull and the dura mater. It is often associated with a more acute presentation following head trauma, usually involving arterial bleeding, and is less common in the elderly unless there is a direct skull fracture involving the middle meningeal artery.

 

Option C. SAH (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage): A subarachnoid hemorrhage presents as hyperdensity in the basal cisterns, sulci, or along the surface of the brain on CT. It is most commonly associated with ruptured aneurysms and would not present with a crescent or banana-shaped lesion as seen in the provided CT image.

 

Option D. Contusion: A contusion would show localized areas of bleeding or edema within the brain tissue itself, often with a mixed density appearance due to the presence of both hemorrhage and edema. Contusions do not have the crescent shape seen with SDH.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Chronic Subdural Hematoma (SDH) is often seen in elderly patients with a history of minor trauma, presenting weeks after the injury with symptoms such as headache, confusion, or neurological deficits. The characteristic CT finding is a crescent-shaped collection along the convexity of the brain, distinguishing it from other types of intracranial hemorrhages.

questions.text: Identify: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Venous ulcer

 

The correct answer is Venous ulcer. Venous ulcers, also known as ulcers of varicose veins, typically occur on the medial aspect of the lower leg, just above the medial malleolus. They are often found in the "gaiter" area and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. The ulcers are usually shallow with irregular borders, and the surrounding skin may show signs of venous stasis, such as hyperpigmentation and edema. The presence of varicose veins and the ulcer's location on the medial side strongly indicate a venous origin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ischemic ulcer: Ischemic ulcers are generally located on the tips of toes, pressure points, or other areas that experience reduced blood flow. They have well-defined borders and a punched-out appearance. The location and presentation in this case do not match ischemic ulcers.

 

Option C. Trophic ulcer: Trophic ulcers are usually associated with neuropathy, often seen in diabetic patients. They occur on pressure points such as the plantar surface of the foot and are characterized by a loss of protective sensation. The location above the medial malleolus does not fit with trophic ulcers.

 

Option D.  Infectious ulcer: Infectious ulcers can occur anywhere on the body and are characterized by overt signs of infection like pus, redness, and warmth. While infection can complicate venous ulcers, the primary cause in this case is venous insufficiency, not infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Venous ulcers are typically found on the medial aspect of the lower leg, above the medial malleolus, and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. Recognizing their characteristic location and appearance is crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with a swelling in the groin region. A diagnosis of direct inguinal hernia is made. Weakness in which of the following structures is most likely to cause this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conjoint tendon

 

  • A direct inguinal hernia occurs when abdominal contents herniate through a weak point in the fascia of the abdominal wall.
  • This type of hernia protrudes through the Hesselbach's triangle, which is defined by the rectus abdominis muscle medially, the inferior epigastric vessels laterally, and the inguinal ligament inferiorly.
  • The conjoint tendon, which is formed by the merging of the transversus abdominis and internal oblique muscles, makes up the main part of the medial portion of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  • Weakness in the conjoint tendon is most likely to cause a direct inguinal hernia.

 

Direct Inguinal Hernia

 

  • Pathophysiology: Arises from Hesselbach’s triangle, medial to the inferior epigastric artery.
  • Mechanism: Due to weakness in the conjoint tendon.
  • Key Feature: Protrudes directly through the abdominal wall without passing through the inguinal canal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectineal ligament: The pectineal ligament (Cooper's ligament) is a thickened band of periosteum along the pectineal line of the pubis. It is not typically involved in the development of direct inguinal hernias.

 

Option C. Reflected part of inguinal ligament: The reflected part of the inguinal ligament is a part of the external oblique aponeurosis and is not the primary structure associated with the weakness leading to direct inguinal hernias.

 

Option D. Lacunar ligament: The lacunar ligament forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal and is associated more with femoral hernias rather than inguinal hernias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Direct inguinal hernias result from a weakness in the conjoint tendon, which forms a crucial part of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  •  This anatomical weakness allows abdominal contents to protrude directly through the abdominal wall within Hesselbach’s triangle.

choices.text: Penectomy with bilateral superficial inguinal dissection

questions.text: A Patient presented with a growth on the penis, which was diagnosed as a T3 cancer without lymph node metastasis. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penectomy with bilateral ilio-inguinal dissection

 

In the case of T3 penile cancer, the tumor has invaded the corpus cavernosum, indicating an advanced stage of the disease. The management of such advanced penile cancer requires aggressive treatment to control both the primary tumor and the potential spread to lymph nodes.

 

The recommended approach includes penectomy to remove the primary tumor and ilio-inguinal lymph node dissection as a prophylactic measure. This is because, even though there are no clinically detectable lymph node metastases (N0), the risk of micro-metastasis is significant in T3 cancers. Ilio-inguinal dissection encompasses both superficial and deep inguinal lymph nodes and provides comprehensive regional control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penectomy: While penectomy addresses the primary tumor, it does not manage the risk of lymphatic spread, which is critical in advanced stages like T3. This option alone is insufficient for comprehensive cancer management.

 

Option B. Penectomy with superficial inguinal dissection: Superficial inguinal dissection alone is outdated and considered inadequate, as it does not address the deeper lymph nodes where metastasis may occur. Current guidelines favor a more extensive approach, including both superficial and deep nodes.

 

Option D. Penectomy with orchidectomy: Orchidectomy is not a part of the standard management for penile cancer, as it involves the removal of the testes and is relevant in testicular cancer, not penile cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For T3 penile cancer without lymph node metastasis, the standard management is penectomy along with ilio-inguinal lymph node dissection to address both the primary tumor and potential regional spread.

questions.text: Identify the procedure based on the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nissen Fundoplication

 

The correct procedure is Nissen Fundoplication. Nissen fundoplication involves a complete 360-degree wrap of the gastric fundus around the lower esophagus to reinforce the lower esophageal sphincter, which helps prevent gastroesophageal reflux. The image shows a complete wrap around the gastroesophageal junction, characteristic of the Nissen procedure. This procedure is commonly performed to treat severe gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or hiatal hernia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Toupet Fundoplication: Toupet fundoplication is a partial (270-degree) posterior wrap of the gastric fundus around the esophagus. This procedure is less constrictive than Nissen fundoplication and is often used in patients with esophageal motility disorders. The image does not depict the 270-degree posterior wrap seen in Toupet fundoplication.

 

Option C. Dor Fundoplication: Dor fundoplication is a partial (180-200 degree) anterior wrap of the gastric fundus around the esophagus. It is often used as a complementary procedure to surgeries such as Heller myotomy for achalasia. The wrap shown in the image is complete and not partial, ruling out Dor fundoplication.

 

Option D. Gastrectomy: Gastrectomy refers to the surgical removal of part or all of the stomach, often performed for conditions like gastric cancer or severe peptic ulcer disease. The image does not show any removal of stomach tissue, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Nissen Fundoplication is a surgical procedure involving a complete 360-degree wrap of the gastric fundus around the lower esophagus to prevent gastroesophageal reflux. It is distinct from other partial fundoplication techniques such as Toupet and Dor, which involve less than a full wrap.

questions.text: Identify the stage of the pressure sore:  (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

A stage 4 pressure sore is characterized by full-thickness tissue loss with exposed bone, tendon, or muscle. The image shows a deep ulcer with visible bone and extensive tissue damage, which are hallmarks of a stage 4 pressure sore. This stage represents the most severe form of pressure ulcer, with significant risk for infection and complications due to the depth of tissue involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: This stage involves non-blanching erythema of intact skin. It is the earliest stage of pressure ulceration, where the skin appears red and does not turn white when pressed.

 

Option B. Stage 2: Stage 2 pressure sores involve partial-thickness skin loss with exposure of the dermis. They may appear as shallow, open ulcers with a red or pink wound bed, without slough or deeper tissue exposure.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Stage 3 sores show full-thickness skin loss, where subcutaneous fat may be visible but bone, tendon, or muscle are not exposed. The ulcer may include undermining and tunneling but does not extend into deeper structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stage 4 pressure sores are the most advanced, involving full-thickness tissue loss with visible bone, muscle, or tendon. Early identification and treatment of pressure sores can prevent progression to this severe stage.
